title: Clever is not always better
comment: Make the code a little bit less clever in order to make it easier to read. Give it a stronger narrative structure so that you can more easily understand the code.
author: gtruitt

title: One React component per file
comment:
Only include one React component per file.
However, multiple Stateless, or Pure, Components are allowed per file. eslint: react/no-multi-comp.

title: Always use JSX syntax
comment: Always use JSX syntax.

title: Do not use React.createElement
comment: Do not use React.createElement unless you’re initializing the app from a file that is not JSX.

title: When react/forbid-prop-types allows arrays and objects
comment: react/forbid-prop-types will allow arrays and objects only if it is explicitly noted what array and object contains, using arrayOf, objectOf, or shape.

title: Class vs React.createClass vs stateless
comment: If you have internal state and/or refs, prefer class extends React.Component over React.createClass. eslint: react/prefer-es6-class react/prefer-stateless-function. And if you don’t have state or refs, prefer normal functions (not arrow functions) over classes:

title: Do not use mixins
comment:
Do not use mixins. 

Why? Mixins introduce implicit dependencies, cause name clashes, and cause snowballing complexity. Most use cases for mixins can be accomplished in better ways via components, higher-order components, or utility modules.

title: Extension naming
comment: Extensions: Use .jsx extension for React components. eslint: react/jsx-filename-extension

title: File naming
comment: Use PascalCase for filenames. E.g., ReservationCard.jsx.

title: Reference naming
comment:
Use the filename as the component name. For example, ReservationCard.jsx should have a reference name of ReservationCard. 

However, for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name:

title: Component naming
comment:
Use the filename as the component name. For example, ReservationCard.jsx should have a reference name of ReservationCard. 

However, for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name:

title: Higher-Order Component naming
comment: Use a composite of the higher-order component’s name and the passed-in component’s name as the displayName on the generated component. For example, the higher-order component withFoo(), when passed a component Bar should produce a component with a displayName of withFoo(Bar).

title: Props naming
comment:
Avoid using DOM component prop names for different purposes. 

Why? People expect props like style and className to mean one specific thing. Varying this API for a subset of your app makes the code less readable and less maintainable, and may cause bugs.

title: Declaration
comment: Do not use displayName for naming components. Instead, name the component by reference.

title: Alignment
comment: Follow these alignment styles for JSX syntax. eslint: react/jsx-closing-bracket-location react/jsx-closing-tag-location

title: Quotes
comment:
Always use double quotes (") for JSX attributes, but single quotes (') for all other JS. eslint: jsx-quotes

Why? Regular HTML attributes also typically use double quotes instead of single, so JSX attributes mirror this convention.

title: Spacing for self-closing tag
comment: Always include a single space in your self-closing tag. eslint: no-multi-spaces, react/jsx-tag-spacing

title: Spacing for JSX curly braces
comment: Do not pad JSX curly braces with spaces. eslint: react/jsx-curly-spacing

title: camelCase for prop names
comment: Always use camelCase for prop names, or PascalCase if the prop value is a React component.

title: Omit value of prop when explicitly true
comment: Omit the value of the prop when it is explicitly true. eslint: react/jsx-boolean-value

title: Alt prop on tags
comment: Always include an alt prop on tags. If the image is presentational, alt can be an empty string or the must have role="presentation". eslint: jsx-a11y/alt-text

title: Avoid unecessary words in alt props
comment: Do not use words like "image", "photo", or "picture" in alt props. eslint: jsx-a11y/img-redundant-alt Why? Screenreaders already announce img elements as images, so there is no need to include this information in the alt text.

title: Use only valid, non-abstract ARIA roles
comment: Use only valid, non-abstract ARIA roles. eslint: jsx-a11y/aria-role

title: Do not use accessKey on elements
comment:
Do not use accessKey on elements. eslint: jsx-a11y/no-access-key

Why? Inconsistencies between keyboard shortcuts and keyboard commands used by people using screenreaders and keyboards complicate accessibility.

title: Avoid using an array index as key prop
comment:
Avoid using an array index as key prop, prefer a stable ID. eslint: react/no-array-index-key

Avoid using an array index as key prop, prefer a stable ID. eslint: react/no-array-index-key
Why? Not using a stable ID is an anti-pattern because it can negatively impact performance and cause issues with component state.

title: Indexes for keys
comment: Don’t use indexes for keys if the order of items may change.

title: define explicit defaultProps
comment:
Always define explicit defaultProps for all non-required props.

Why? propTypes are a form of documentation, and providing defaultProps means the reader of your code doesn’t have to assume as much. In addition, it can mean that your code can omit certain type checks.

title: Spread props
comment:
Use spread props sparingly.

Why? Otherwise you’re more likely to pass unnecessary props down to components. And for React v15.6.1 and older, you could pass invalid HTML attributes to the DOM.

See Supporting Document for exceptions, though.

title: Refs
comment: Always use ref callbacks. eslint: react/no-string-refs

title: Parentheses
comment: Wrap JSX tags in parentheses when they span more than one line. eslint: react/jsx-wrap-multilines

title: Self-close tags
comment: Always self-close tags that have no children. eslint: react/self-closing-comp

title: Tags for multi-line components
comment: If your component has multiline properties, close its tag on a new line. eslint: react/jsx-closing-bracket-location

title: Arrow functions in methods
comment:
Use arrow functions to close over local variables. It is handy when you need to pass additional data to an event handler. 

See Supporting Document for considerations, though.

title: Event handlers for the render method
comment:
Bind event handlers for the render method in the constructor. eslint: react/jsx-no-bind

Why? A bind call in the render path creates a brand new function on every single render. Do not use arrow functions in class fields, because it makes them challenging to test and debug, and can negatively impact performance, and because conceptually, class fields are for data, not logic.

title: Underscore prefix for internal methods
comment:
Do not use underscore prefix for internal methods of a React component.

Why? Underscore prefixes are sometimes used as a convention in other languages to denote privacy. But, unlike those languages, there is no native support for privacy in JavaScript, everything is public. 

Regardless of your intentions, adding underscore prefixes to your properties does not actually make them private, and any property (underscore-prefixed or not) should be treated as being public.

title: Value in render methods
comment: Be sure to return a value in your render methods. eslint: react/require-render-return

title: Follow consistent ordering for class extends
comment:
Follow consistent ordering for class extends React.Component.

See Supporting Document for list.

title: Follow consistent definitions
comment:
Define propTypes, defaultProps, contextTypes, etc. consistently. 

See Supporting Document for list.

title: Follow consistent ordering for React.createClass
comment:
Following consistent ordering for React.createClass: eslint: react/sort-comp

See Supporting Document for list.

title: isMounted
comment:
Do not use isMounted. eslint: react/no-is-mounted

Why? isMounted is an anti-pattern, is not available when using ES6 classes, and is on its way to being officially deprecated.

title: Logic should be in the positive
comment: Logic should in general be asking the question "Is this true?" instead of "Is this not true?"

title: Iterate in Thens
comment: You should iterate sequentially on a focused chunk of work at a time.
author: Adam Craven

title: Enforce coding rules autoamtically
comment: Code should be formatted the same way and enforced automatically using tools.
author: Adam Craven

title: Avoid double negative logic
comment: Conditional logic should avoid double negatives.

title: Open–closed principle
comment: Software entities should be open for extension, but closed for modification.

title: Single-Responsibility Principle
comment: Every module, class or function in a computer program should have responsibility over a single part of that program's functionality, and it should encapsulate that part
author: Robert C. Martin

title: Reduce a problem to its lowest sensible abstraction
comment: Stating a problem in its lowest sensible abstraction helps you understand and develop accurate solutions to a problem.
author: Adam Craven

title: Documentation should be close to the code
comment: Documentation, in all forms, should be as close as it can be to the code.
author: Adam Craven

title: Compute properties when possible
comment: Compute properties when possible
author: Adam Craven

title: One single source of truth
comment: Data should be held in one location, duplicates of that data should be by reference only.

title: Make the invisible, visible
comment: Make the hidden principles, ideas and behaviors which make up a technology organization understood and explicit
author: Adam Craven

title: Ensure documentation is easy to amend
comment: When encountering documentation, it should be easy to make changes.
author: Adam Craven

title: Software should be easy to debug
comment: When software behaves unexpectedly, it should be easy to understand what is causing the problem.
author: Adam Craven

title: Separate core logic from the framework
comment: Core logic that is related to solving a business or domain problem should exist outside of a framework.
author: Adam Craven

title: Relative Path Traversal
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as .. that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: External Control of System or Configuration Setting
comment: One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user.

title: Absolute Path Traversal
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as /abs/path that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Improper Resolution of Path Equivalence
comment: The system or application is vulnerable to file system contents disclosure through path equivalence. Path equivalence involves the use of special characters in file and directory names. The associated manipulations are intended to generate multiple names for the same object.

title: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')
comment: The software attempts to access a file based on the filename, but it does not properly prevent that filename from identifying a link or shortcut that resolves to an unintended resource.

title: Improper Handling of File Names that Identify Virtual Resources
comment: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a file name that identifies a virtual resource that is not directly specified within the directory that is associated with the file name, causing the product to perform file-based operations on a resource that is not a file.

title: External Control of File Name or Path
comment: The software allows user input to control or influence paths or file names that are used in filesystem operations.

title: Improper Neutralization of Equivalent Special Elements
comment: The software properly neutralizes certain special elements, but it improperly neutralizes equivalent special elements.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

title: Improper Neutralization of Argument Delimiters in a Command ('Argument Injection')
comment: The software constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere, but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments, options, or switches within that command string.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an LDAP Query ('LDAP Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of an LDAP query using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended LDAP query when it is sent to a downstream component.

title: XML Injection (aka Blind XPath Injection)
comment: The software does not properly neutralize special elements that are used in XML, allowing attackers to modify the syntax, content, or commands of the XML before it is processed by an end system.

title: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences ('CRLF Injection')
comment: The software uses CRLF (carriage return line feeds) as a special element, e.g. to separate lines or records, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CRLF sequences from inputs.

title: Improper Control of Generation of Code ('Code Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of a code segment using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the syntax or behavior of the intended code segment.

title: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Statically Saved Code ('Static Code Injection')
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before inserting the input into an executable resource, such as a library, configuration file, or template.

title: Missing XML Validation
comment: The software accepts XML from an untrusted source but does not validate the XML against the proper schema.

title: Misinterpretation of Input
comment: The software misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.

title: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

title: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
comment: The program copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow.

title: Write-what-where Condition
comment: Any condition where the attacker has the ability to write an arbitrary value to an arbitrary location, often as the result of a buffer overflow.

title: Buffer Underwrite ('Buffer Underflow')
comment: The software writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer.

title: Out-of-bounds Read
comment: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer.

title: Wrap-around Error
comment: Wrap around errors occur whenever a value is incremented past the maximum value for its type and therefore wraps around to a very small, negative, or undefined value.

title: Improper Validation of Array Index
comment: The product uses untrusted input when calculating or using an array index, but the product does not validate or incorrectly validates the index to ensure the index references a valid position within the array.

title: Improper Handling of Length Parameter Inconsistency
comment: The software parses a formatted message or structure, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a length field that is inconsistent with the actual length of the associated data.

title: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size
comment: The software does not correctly calculate the size to be used when allocating a buffer, which could lead to a buffer overflow.

title: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
comment: The software uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

title: Incorrect Calculation of Multi-Byte String Length
comment: The software does not correctly calculate the length of strings that can contain wide or multi-byte characters.

title: Improper Neutralization of Delimiters
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes delimiters.

title: Improper Handling of Missing Special Element
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an expected special element is missing.

title: Improper Handling of Additional Special Element
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an additional unexpected special element is provided.

title: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Special Elements
comment: The software does not properly handle input in which an inconsistency exists between two or more special characters or reserved words.

title: Improper Null Termination
comment: The software does not terminate or incorrectly terminates a string or array with a null character or equivalent terminator.

title: Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity
comment: The software does not properly account for differences in case sensitivity when accessing or determining the properties of a resource, leading to inconsistent results.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Validation
comment: The software validates input before applying protection mechanisms that modify the input, which could allow an attacker to bypass the validation via dangerous inputs that only arise after the modification.

title: Collapse of Data into Unsafe Value
comment: The software filters data in a way that causes it to be reduced or collapsed into an unsafe value that violates an expected security property.

title: Permissive List of Allowed Inputs
comment: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are explicitly allowed by policy because the inputs are assumed to be safe, but the list is too permissive - that is, it allows an input that is unsafe, leading to resultant weaknesses.

title: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs
comment: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses.

title: Overly Restrictive Regular Expression
comment: A regular expression is overly restrictive, which prevents dangerous values from being detected.

title: Reliance on Data/Memory Layout
comment: The software makes invalid assumptions about how protocol data or memory is organized at a lower level, resulting in unintended program behavior.

title: Integer Overflow or Wraparound
comment: The software performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

title: Integer Underflow (Wrap or Wraparound)
comment: The product subtracts one value from another, such that the result is less than the minimum allowable integer value, which produces a value that is not equal to the correct result.

title: Integer Coercion Error
comment: Integer coercion refers to a set of flaws pertaining to the type casting, extension, or truncation of primitive data types.

title: Off-by-one Error
comment: A product calculates or uses an incorrect maximum or minimum value that is 1 more, or 1 less, than the correct value.

title: Numeric Truncation Error
comment: Truncation errors occur when a primitive is cast to a primitive of a smaller size and data is lost in the conversion.

title: Use of Incorrect Byte Ordering
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not account for byte ordering (e.g. big-endian and little-endian) when processing the input, causing an incorrect number or value to be used.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Sent Data
comment: The code transmits data to another actor, but the data contains sensitive information that should not be accessible to the actor that is receiving the data.

title: Observable Response Discrepancy
comment: The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy
comment: The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process, or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality.

title: Observable Timing Discrepancy
comment: Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

title: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The software generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

title: Improper Removal of Sensitive Information Before Storage or Transfer
comment: The product stores, transfers, or shares a resource that contains sensitive information, but it does not properly remove that information before the product makes the resource available to unauthorized actors.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information Due to Incompatible Policies
comment: The product's intended functionality exposes information to certain actors in accordance with the developer's security policy, but this information is regarded as sensitive according to the intended security policies of other stakeholders such as the product's administrator, users, or others whose information is being processed.

title: Invocation of Process Using Visible Sensitive Information
comment: A process is invoked with sensitive command-line arguments, environment variables, or other elements that can be seen by other processes on the operating system.

title: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code
comment: The application inserts sensitive information into debugging code, which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production.

title: Truncation of Security-relevant Information
comment: The application truncates the display, recording, or processing of security-relevant information in a way that can obscure the source or nature of an attack.

title: Omission of Security-relevant Information
comment: The application does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

title: Obscured Security-relevant Information by Alternate Name
comment: The software records security-relevant information according to an alternate name of the affected entity, instead of the canonical name.

title: Sensitive Information Uncleared in Resource Before Release for Reuse
comment: The product prepares to release a resource such as memory or a file so that the resource can be reused by other entities, but the product does not fully clear previously-used sensitive information from that resource before the resource is released.

title: Improper Handling of Values
comment: The software does not properly handle when the expected number of values for parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those values are undefined.

title: Improper Handling of Parameters
comment: The software does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

title: Improper Handling of Structural Elements
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles inputs that are related to complex structures.

title: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type, e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).

title: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
comment: The program calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.

title: Creation of chroot Jail Without Changing Working Directory
comment: The program uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.

title: Uncaught Exception
comment: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.

title: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
comment: The software performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

title: Unchecked Return Value
comment: The software does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.

title: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
comment: The software incorrectly checks a return value from a function, which prevents the software from detecting errors or exceptional conditions.

title: Unprotected Storage of Credentials
comment: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.

title: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format
comment: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other accounts.

title: Password in Configuration File
comment: The software stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

title: Weak Encoding for Password
comment: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.

title: Not Using Password Aging
comment: If no mechanism is in place for managing password aging, users will have no incentive to update passwords in a timely manner.

title: Password Aging with Long Expiration
comment: Allowing password aging to occur unchecked can result in the possibility of diminished password integrity.

title: Incorrect Privilege Assignment
comment: A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

title: Privilege Defined With Unsafe Actions
comment: A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.

title: Privilege Chaining
comment: Two distinct privileges, roles, capabilities, or rights can be combined in a way that allows an entity to perform unsafe actions that would not be allowed without that combination.

title: Privilege Context Switching Error
comment: The software does not properly manage privileges while it is switching between different contexts that have different privileges or spheres of control.

title: Least Privilege Violation
comment: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

title: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
comment: The software attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.

title: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.

title: Incorrect Default Permissions
comment: The product, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.

title: Insecure Inherited Permissions
comment: A product defines a set of insecure permissions that are inherited by objects that are created by the program.

title: Insecure Preserved Inherited Permissions
comment: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.

title: Incorrect Execution-Assigned Permissions
comment: While it is executing, the software sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.

title: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges
comment: The application does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the application in an invalid state.

title: Improper Preservation of Permissions
comment: The software does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.

title: Unverified Ownership
comment: The software does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.

title: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel
comment: A product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

title: Authentication Bypass by Spoofing
comment: This attack-focused weakness is caused by improperly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.

title: Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay
comment: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the software makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).

title: Improper Certificate Validation
comment: The software does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.

title: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
comment: The software does not follow, or incorrectly follows, the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate, resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate.

title: Improper Check for Certificate Revocation
comment: The software does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate, which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised.

title: Incorrect Implementation of Authentication Algorithm
comment: The requirements for the software dictate the use of an established authentication algorithm, but the implementation of the algorithm is incorrect.

title: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
comment: The software implements an authentication technique, but it skips a step that weakens the technique.

title: Authentication Bypass by Primary Weakness
comment: The authentication algorithm is sound, but the implemented mechanism can be bypassed as the result of a separate weakness that is primary to the authentication error.

title: Missing Authentication for Critical Function
comment: The software does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

title: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts
comment: The software does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within in a short time frame, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

title: Use of Single-factor Authentication
comment: The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme.

title: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
comment: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings, each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

title: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

title: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in GUI
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext within the GUI.

title: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
comment: The software transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

title: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key
comment: The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

title: Key Exchange without Entity Authentication
comment: The software performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor.

title: Reusing a Nonce, Key Pair in Encryption
comment: Nonces should be used for the present occasion and only once.

title: Use of a Key Past its Expiration Date
comment: The product uses a cryptographic key or password past its expiration date, which diminishes its safety significantly by increasing the timing window for cracking attacks against that key.

title: Missing Required Cryptographic Step
comment: The product does not implement a required step in a cryptographic algorithm, resulting in weaker encryption than advertised by that algorithm.

title: Reversible One-Way Hash
comment: The product uses a hashing algorithm that produces a hash value that can be used to determine the original input, or to find an input that can produce the same hash, more efficiently than brute force techniques.

title: Insufficient Entropy
comment: The software uses an algorithm or scheme that produces insufficient entropy, leaving patterns or clusters of values that are more likely to occur than others.

title: Small Space of Random Values
comment: The number of possible random values is smaller than needed by the product, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

title: Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
comment: The software uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) that does not correctly manage seeds.

title: Use of Cryptographically Weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
comment: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) in a security context, but the PRNG's algorithm is not cryptographically strong.

title: Predictable from Observable State
comment: A number or object is predictable based on observations that the attacker can make about the state of the system or network, such as time, process ID, etc.

title: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values
comment: An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values.

title: Predictable Value Range from Previous Values
comment: The software's random number generator produces a series of values which, when observed, can be used to infer a relatively small range of possibilities for the next value that could be generated.

title: Origin Validation Error
comment: The software does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

title: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature
comment: The software does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

title: Use of Less Trusted Source
comment: The software has two different sources of the same data or information, but it uses the source that has less support for verification, is less trusted, or is less resistant to attack.

title: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data
comment: The software, when processing trusted data, accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data, treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

title: Insufficient Type Distinction
comment: The software does not properly distinguish between different types of elements in a way that leads to insecure behavior.

title: Missing Support for Integrity Check
comment: The software uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum.

title: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
comment: The software does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or checksums of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission.

title: Product UI does not Warn User of Unsafe Actions
comment: The software's user interface does not warn the user before undertaking an unsafe action on behalf of that user. This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system.

title: Insufficient UI Warning of Dangerous Operations
comment: The user interface provides a warning to a user regarding dangerous or sensitive operations, but the warning is not noticeable enough to warrant attention.

title: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
comment: The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

title: Race Condition Enabling Link Following
comment: The software checks the status of a file or directory before accessing it, which produces a race condition in which the file can be replaced with a link before the access is performed, causing the software to access the wrong file.

title: Signal Handler Race Condition
comment: The software uses a signal handler that introduces a race condition.

title: Race Condition in Switch
comment: The code contains a switch statement in which the switched variable can be modified while the switch is still executing, resulting in unexpected behavior.

title: Race Condition within a Thread
comment: If two threads of execution use a resource simultaneously, there exists the possibility that resources may be used while invalid, in turn making the state of execution undefined.

title: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
comment: The software checks the state of a resource before using that resource, but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the software to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state.

title: Context Switching Race Condition
comment: A product performs a series of non-atomic actions to switch between contexts that cross privilege or other security boundaries, but a race condition allows an attacker to modify or misrepresent the product's behavior during the switch.

title: Divide By Zero
comment: The product divides a value by zero.

title: Incomplete Internal State Distinction
comment: The software does not properly determine which state it is in, causing it to assume it is in state X when in fact it is in state Y, causing it to perform incorrect operations in a security-relevant manner.

title: Passing Mutable Objects to an Untrusted Method
comment: The program sends non-cloned mutable data as an argument to a method or function.

title: Returning a Mutable Object to an Untrusted Caller
comment: Sending non-cloned mutable data as a return value may result in that data being altered or deleted by the calling function.

title: Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions
comment: Opening temporary files without appropriate measures or controls can leave the file, its contents and any function that it impacts vulnerable to attack.

title: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions
comment: The software creates a temporary file in a directory whose permissions allow unintended actors to determine the file's existence or otherwise access that file.

title: Covert Timing Channel
comment: Covert timing channels convey information by modulating some aspect of system behavior over time, so that the program receiving the information can observe system behavior and infer protected information.

title: Symbolic Name not Mapping to Correct Object
comment: A constant symbolic reference to an object is used, even though the reference can resolve to a different object over time.

title: Detection of Error Condition Without Action
comment: The software detects a specific error, but takes no actions to handle the error.

title: Unchecked Error Condition
comment: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

title: Missing Report of Error Condition
comment: The software encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred.

title: Return of Wrong Status Code
comment: A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate an error, but causes the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result.

title: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
comment: The software does not properly check when a function or operation returns a value that is legitimate for the function, but is not expected by the software.

title: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
comment: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer.

title: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
comment: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

title: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
comment: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

title: Exposure of File Descriptor to Unintended Control Sphere ('File Descriptor Leak')
comment: A process does not close sensitive file descriptors before invoking a child process, which allows the child to perform unauthorized I/O operations using those descriptors.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Amplification
comment: The software allows an entity to perform a legitimate but expensive operation before authentication or authorization has taken place.

title: Improper Handling of Highly Compressed Data (Data Amplification)
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.

title: Insufficient Resource Pool
comment: The software's resource pool is not large enough to handle peak demand, which allows an attacker to prevent others from accessing the resource by using a (relatively) large number of requests for resources.

title: Unrestricted Externally Accessible Lock
comment: The software properly checks for the existence of a lock, but the lock can be externally controlled or influenced by an actor that is outside of the intended sphere of control.

title: Improper Resource Locking
comment: The software does not lock or does not correctly lock a resource when the software must have exclusive access to the resource.

title: Missing Lock Check
comment: A product does not check to see if a lock is present before performing sensitive operations on a resource.

title: Unprotected Primary Channel
comment: The software uses a primary channel for administration or restricted functionality, but it does not properly protect the channel.

title: Unprotected Alternate Channel
comment: The software protects a primary channel, but it does not use the same level of protection for an alternate channel.

title: Race Condition During Access to Alternate Channel
comment: The product opens an alternate channel to communicate with an authorized user, but the channel is accessible to other actors.

title: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
comment: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs, scripts, or files.

title: Untrusted Search Path
comment: The application searches for critical resources using an externally-supplied search path that can point to resources that are not under the application's direct control.

title: Uncontrolled Search Path Element
comment: The product uses a fixed or controlled search path to find resources, but one or more locations in that path can be under the control of unintended actors.

title: Unquoted Search Path or Element
comment: The product uses a search path that contains an unquoted element, in which the element contains whitespace or other separators. This can cause the product to access resources in a parent path.

title: Deployment of Wrong Handler
comment: The wrong handler is assigned to process an object.

title: Missing Handler
comment: A handler is not available or implemented.

title: Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations
comment: The application uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers, but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running.

title: Unparsed Raw Web Content Delivery
comment: The software stores raw content or supporting code under the web document root with an extension that is not specifically handled by the server.

title: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
comment: The software allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

title: Incomplete Model of Endpoint Features
comment: A product acts as an intermediary or monitor between two or more endpoints, but it does not have a complete model of an endpoint's features, behaviors, or state, potentially causing the product to perform incorrect actions based on this incomplete model.

title: Behavioral Change in New Version or Environment
comment: A's behavior or functionality changes with a new version of A, or a new environment, which is not known (or manageable) by B.

title: Expected Behavior Violation
comment: A feature, API, or function being used by a product behaves differently than the product expects.

title: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request Smuggling')
comment: When malformed or abnormal HTTP requests are interpreted by one or more entities in the data flow between the user and the web server, such as a proxy or firewall, they can be interpreted inconsistently, allowing the attacker to smuggle a request to one device without the other device being aware of it.

title: Unimplemented or Unsupported Feature in UI
comment: A UI function for a security feature appears to be supported and gives feedback to the user that suggests that it is supported, but the underlying functionality is not implemented.

title: Obsolete Feature in UI
comment: A UI function is obsolete and the product does not warn the user.

title: The UI Performs the Wrong Action
comment: The UI performs the wrong action with respect to the user's request.

title: Multiple Interpretations of UI Input
comment: The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation.

title: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
comment: The software initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors.

title: Non-exit on Failed Initialization
comment: The software does not exit or otherwise modify its operation when security-relevant errors occur during initialization, such as when a configuration file has a format error, which can cause the software to execute in a less secure fashion than intended by the administrator.

title: Incomplete Cleanup
comment: The software does not properly clean up and remove temporary or supporting resources after they have been used.

title: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
comment: The product does not clean up its state or incorrectly cleans up its state when an exception is thrown, leading to unexpected state or control flow.

title: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)
comment: Duplicate keys in associative lists can lead to non-unique keys being mistaken for an error.

title: Deletion of Data Structure Sentinel
comment: The accidental deletion of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

title: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel
comment: The accidental addition of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

title: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range
comment: A function can return a pointer to memory that is outside of the buffer that the pointer is expected to reference.

title: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type
comment: The code calls sizeof() on a malloced pointer type, which always returns the wordsize/8. This can produce an unexpected result if the programmer intended to determine how much memory has been allocated.

title: Incorrect Pointer Scaling
comment: In C and C++, one may often accidentally refer to the wrong memory due to the semantics of when math operations are implicitly scaled.

title: Use of Pointer Subtraction to Determine Size
comment: The application subtracts one pointer from another in order to determine size, but this calculation can be incorrect if the pointers do not exist in the same memory chunk.

title: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')
comment: The application uses external input with reflection to select which classes or code to use, but it does not sufficiently prevent the input from selecting improper classes or code.

title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID)
comment: The software does not properly protect an assumed-immutable element from being modified by an attacker.

title: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter
comment: The web application does not sufficiently verify inputs that are assumed to be immutable but are actually externally controllable, such as hidden form fields.

title: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
comment: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions.

title: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
comment: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

title: NULL Pointer Dereference
comment: A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid, but is NULL, typically causing a crash or exit.

title: Use of Obsolete Function
comment: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

title: Missing Default Case in Switch Statement
comment: The code does not have a default case in a switch statement, which might lead to complex logical errors and resultant weaknesses.

title: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function
comment: The program defines a signal handler that calls a non-reentrant function.

title: Use of Incorrect Operator
comment: The programmer accidentally uses the wrong operator, which changes the application logic in security-relevant ways.

title: Incorrect Block Delimitation
comment: The code does not explicitly delimit a block that is intended to contain 2 or more statements, creating a logic error.

title: Omitted Break Statement in Switch
comment: The program omits a break statement within a switch or similar construct, causing code associated with multiple conditions to execute. This can cause problems when the programmer only intended to execute code associated with one condition.

title: Reliance on Package-level Scope
comment: Java packages are not inherently closed; therefore, relying on them for code security is not a good practice.

title: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session
comment: The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions, causing data to be provided to, or used by, the wrong session.

title: Active Debug Code
comment: The application is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information.

title: Download of Code Without Integrity Check
comment: The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code.

title: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
comment: The application does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the application does.

title: Trust Boundary Violation
comment: The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message.

title: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
comment: The application deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

title: Covert Storage Channel
comment: A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information.

title: Weak Password Requirements
comment: The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts.

title: Unprotected Transport of Credentials
comment: Login pages do not use adequate measures to protect the user name and password while they are in transit from the client to the server.

title: Use of Cache Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The code uses a cache that contains sensitive information, but the cache can be read by an actor outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
comment: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

title: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
comment: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.

title: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
comment: The software does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code, which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses.

title: Suspicious Comment
comment: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs, incomplete functionality, or weaknesses.

title: Use of Hard-coded, Security-relevant Constants
comment: The program uses hard-coded constants instead of symbolic names for security-critical values, which increases the likelihood of mistakes during code maintenance or security policy change.

title: Missing Password Field Masking
comment: The software does not mask passwords during entry, increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization
comment: If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization, it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection.

title: Dead Code
comment: The software contains dead code, which can never be executed.

title: Return of Stack Variable Address
comment: A function returns the address of a stack variable, which will cause unintended program behavior, typically in the form of a crash.

title: Assignment to Variable without Use
comment: The variable's value is assigned but never used, making it a dead store.

title: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking
comment: The application relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations, but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user.

title: Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context
comment: The product does not properly synchronize shared data, such as static variables across threads, which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes.

title: Expression is Always False
comment: The software contains an expression that will always evaluate to false.

title: Expression is Always True
comment: The software contains an expression that will always evaluate to true.

title: clone() Method Without super.clone()
comment: The software contains a clone() method that does not call super.clone() to obtain the new object.

title: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined
comment: The software does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects.

title: Return Inside Finally Block
comment: The code has a return statement inside a finally block, which will cause any thrown exception in the try block to be discarded.

title: Empty Synchronized Block
comment: The software contains an empty synchronized block.

title: Explicit Call to Finalize()
comment: The software makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer.

title: Assignment of a Fixed Address to a Pointer
comment: The software sets a pointer to a specific address other than NULL or 0.

title: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
comment: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.

title: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents
comment: The program compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves, preventing it from detecting equivalent objects.

title: Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison
comment: The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string, such as using == when the equals() method should be used instead.

title: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
comment: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions, which may reveal sensitive debugging information.

title: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
comment: A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks.

title: Use of Client-Side Authentication
comment: A client/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code, allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check.

title: Multiple Binds to the Same Port
comment: When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port, other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed.

title: Unchecked Input for Loop Condition
comment: The product does not properly check inputs that are used for loop conditions, potentially leading to a denial of service because of excessive looping.

title: Double-Checked Locking
comment: The program uses double-checked locking to access a resource without the overhead of explicit synchronization, but the locking is insufficient.

title: Improper Restriction of XML External Entity Reference
comment: The software processes an XML document that can contain XML entities with URIs that resolve to documents outside of the intended sphere of control, causing the product to embed incorrect documents into its output.

title: Improper Authorization of Index Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents, but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information.

title: Insufficient Session Expiration
comment: According to WASC, Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization.

title: Reachable Assertion
comment: The product contains an assert() or similar statement that can be triggered by an attacker, which leads to an application exit or other behavior that is more severe than necessary.

title: Exposed Unsafe ActiveX Method
comment: An ActiveX control is intended for use in a web browser, but it exposes dangerous methods that perform actions that are outside of the browser's security model (e.g. the zone or domain).

title: Dangling Database Cursor ('Cursor Injection')
comment: If a database cursor is not closed properly, then it could become accessible to other users while retaining the same privileges that were originally assigned, leaving the cursor dangling.

title: Unverified Password Change
comment: When setting a new password for a user, the product does not require knowledge of the original password, or using another form of authentication.

title: Variable Extraction Error
comment: The product uses external input to determine the names of variables into which information is extracted, without verifying that the names of the specified variables are valid. This could cause the program to overwrite unintended variables.

title: Executable Regular Expression Error
comment: The product uses a regular expression that either (1) contains an executable component with user-controlled inputs, or (2) allows a user to enable execution by inserting pattern modifiers.

title: Permissive Regular Expression
comment: The product uses a regular expression that does not sufficiently restrict the set of allowed values.

title: Dynamic Variable Evaluation
comment: In a language where the user can influence the name of a variable at runtime, if the variable names are not controlled, an attacker can read or write to arbitrary variables, or access arbitrary functions.

title: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments
comment: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified, leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses.

title: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
comment: The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data.

title: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password
comment: The software contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password, but the mechanism is weak.

title: Improper Restriction of Names for Files and Other Resources
comment: The application constructs the name of a file or other resource using input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the resulting name.

title: Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection')
comment: The software uses external input to dynamically construct an XPath expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.

title: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism
comment: The software contains an account lockout protection mechanism, but the mechanism is too restrictive and can be triggered too easily, which allows attackers to deny service to legitimate users by causing their accounts to be locked out.

title: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs
comment: The application does not conform to the API requirements for a function call that requires extra privileges. This could allow attackers to gain privileges by causing the function to be called incorrectly.

title: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking
comment: The software uses obfuscation or encryption of inputs that should not be mutable by an external actor, but the software does not use integrity checks to detect if those inputs have been modified.

title: Improper Neutralization of Data within XQuery Expressions ('XQuery Injection')
comment: The software uses external input to dynamically construct an XQuery expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.

title: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context
comment: The software calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

title: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function
comment: The program invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.

title: Incorrect Conversion between Numeric Types
comment: When converting from one data type to another, such as long to integer, data can be omitted or translated in a way that produces unexpected values. If the resulting values are used in a sensitive context, then dangerous behaviors may occur.

title: Use of Multiple Resources with Duplicate Identifier
comment: The software uses multiple resources that can have the same identifier, in a context in which unique identifiers are required.

title: Use of Low-Level Functionality
comment: The software uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the software is supposed to operate.

title: Execution After Redirect (EAR)
comment: The web application sends a redirect to another location, but instead of exiting, it executes additional code.

title: Incorrect Ownership Assignment
comment: The software assigns an owner to a resource, but the owner is outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Compiler Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code
comment: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the compiler optimizes the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

title: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
comment: The software provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

title: Missing Custom Error Page
comment: The software does not return custom error pages to the user, possibly exposing sensitive information.

title: Release of Invalid Pointer or Reference
comment: The application attempts to return a memory resource to the system, but calls the wrong release function or calls the appropriate release function incorrectly.

title: Multiple Locks of a Critical Resource
comment: The software locks a critical resource more times than intended, leading to an unexpected state in the system.

title: Multiple Unlocks of a Critical Resource
comment: The software unlocks a critical resource more times than intended, leading to an unexpected state in the system.

title: Critical Data Element Declared Public
comment: The software declares a critical variable, field, or member to be public when intended security policy requires it to be private.

title: Access to Critical Private Variable via Public Method
comment: The software defines a public method that reads or modifies a private variable.

title: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling
comment: The software allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

title: Missing Reference to Active Allocated Resource
comment: The software does not properly maintain a reference to a resource that has been allocated, which prevents the resource from being reclaimed.

title: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime
comment: The software does not release a resource after its effective lifetime has ended, i.e., after the resource is no longer needed.

title: Improper Restriction of Recursive Entity References in DTDs ('XML Entity Expansion')
comment: The software uses XML documents and allows their structure to be defined with a Document Type Definition (DTD), but it does not properly control the number of recursive definitions of entities.

title: Insufficient Logging
comment: When a security-critical event occurs, the software either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

title: Logging of Excessive Data
comment: The software logs too much information, making log files hard to process and possibly hindering recovery efforts or forensic analysis after an attack.

title: Operator Precedence Logic Error
comment: The program uses an expression in which operator precedence causes incorrect logic to be used.

title: Access of Memory Location Before Start of Buffer
comment: The software reads or writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer.

title: Out-of-bounds Write
comment: The software writes data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer.

title: Access of Memory Location After End of Buffer
comment: The software reads or writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location after the end of the buffer.

title: Incomplete Filtering of Special Elements
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but does not completely filter special elements before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Only Filtering Special Elements at a Specified Location
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements at a specified location, thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
comment: The software contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

title: Guessable CAPTCHA
comment: The software uses a CAPTCHA challenge, but the challenge can be guessed or automatically recognized by a non-human actor.

title: Buffer Access with Incorrect Length Value
comment: The software uses a sequential operation to read or write a buffer, but it uses an incorrect length value that causes it to access memory that is outside of the bounds of the buffer.

title: Missing Synchronization
comment: The software utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner but does not attempt to synchronize access to the resource.

title: Incorrect Synchronization
comment: The software utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner, but it does not correctly synchronize access to the resource.

title: Untrusted Pointer Dereference
comment: The program obtains a value from an untrusted source, converts this value to a pointer, and dereferences the resulting pointer.

title: Use of Out-of-range Pointer Offset
comment: The program performs pointer arithmetic on a valid pointer, but it uses an offset that can point outside of the intended range of valid memory locations for the resulting pointer.

title: Access of Uninitialized Pointer
comment: The program accesses or uses a pointer that has not been initialized.

title: Expired Pointer Dereference
comment: The program dereferences a pointer that contains a location for memory that was previously valid, but is no longer valid.

title: Premature Release of Resource During Expected Lifetime
comment: The program releases a resource that is still intended to be used by the program itself or another actor.

title: Signal Handler with Functionality that is not Asynchronous-Safe
comment: The software defines a signal handler that contains code sequences that are not asynchronous-safe, i.e., the functionality is not reentrant, or it can be interrupted.

title: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere
comment: The software imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Signal Handler Function Associated with Multiple Signals
comment: The software defines a function that is used as a handler for more than one signal.

title: Unlock of a Resource that is not Locked
comment: The software attempts to unlock a resource that is not locked.

title: Deadlock
comment: The software contains multiple threads or executable segments that are waiting for each other to release a necessary lock, resulting in deadlock.

title: Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop')
comment: The program contains an iteration or loop with an exit condition that cannot be reached, i.e., an infinite loop.

title: Use of Password Hash Instead of Password for Authentication
comment: The software records password hashes in a data store, receives a hash of a password from a client, and compares the supplied hash to the hash obtained from the data store.

title: Improper Enforcement of a Single, Unique Action
comment: The software requires that an actor should only be able to perform an action once, or to have only one unique action, but the software does not enforce or improperly enforces this restriction.

title: Inappropriate Encoding for Output Context
comment: The software uses or specifies an encoding when generating output to a downstream component, but the specified encoding is not the same as the encoding that is expected by the downstream component.

title: Numeric Range Comparison Without Minimum Check
comment: The program checks a value to ensure that it is less than or equal to a maximum, but it does not also verify that the value is greater than or equal to the minimum.

title: Improper Enforcement of Behavioral Workflow
comment: The software supports a session in which more than one behavior must be performed by an actor, but it does not properly ensure that the actor performs the behaviors in the required sequence.

title: Placement of User into Incorrect Group
comment: The software or the administrator places a user into an incorrect group.

title: Access of Resource Using Incompatible Type ('Type Confusion')
comment: The program allocates or initializes a resource such as a pointer, object, or variable using one type, but it later accesses that resource using a type that is incompatible with the original type.

title: Use of Uninitialized Resource
comment: The software uses or accesses a resource that has not been initialized.

title: Missing Initialization of Resource
comment: The software does not initialize a critical resource.

title: Use of Expired File Descriptor
comment: The software uses or accesses a file descriptor after it has been closed.

title: Improper Update of Reference Count
comment: The software uses a reference count to manage a resource, but it does not update or incorrectly updates the reference count.

title: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables
comment: The software does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables.

title: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component that specifies multiple attributes, properties, or fields that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control which attributes can be modified.

title: Use of Password Hash With Insufficient Computational Effort
comment: The software generates a hash for a password, but it uses a scheme that does not provide a sufficient level of computational effort that would make password cracking attacks infeasible or expensive.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an Expression Language Statement ('Expression Language Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of an expression language (EL) statement in a Java Server Page (JSP) using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended EL statement before it is executed.

title: Improper Restriction of Power Consumption
comment: The software operates in an environment in which power is a limited resource that cannot be automatically replenished, but the software does not properly restrict the amount of power that its operation consumes.

title: Storage of Sensitive Data in a Mechanism without Access Control
comment: The software stores sensitive information in a file system or device that does not have built-in access control.

title: Improper Enforcement of Message Integrity During Transmission in a Communication Channel
comment: The software establishes a communication channel with an endpoint and receives a message from that endpoint, but it does not sufficiently ensure that the message was not modified during transmission.

title: Improper Authorization in Handler for Custom URL Scheme
comment: The software uses a handler for a custom URL scheme, but it does not properly restrict which actors can invoke the handler using the scheme.

title: Improper Verification of Source of a Communication Channel
comment: The software establishes a communication channel to handle an incoming request that has been initiated by an actor, but it does not properly verify that the request is coming from the expected origin.

title: Incorrectly Specified Destination in a Communication Channel
comment: The software creates a communication channel to initiate an outgoing request to an actor, but it does not correctly specify the intended destination for that actor.

title: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
