comment: The software displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

title: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
comment: The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with.

title: Comparison of Incompatible Types
comment: The software performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared.

title: Comparison Using Wrong Factors
comment: The code performs a comparison between two entities, but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities, which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.

title: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code
comment: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

title: Use of Redundant Code
comment: The software has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that contain the same code.

title: Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
comment: The software uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.

title: Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range
comment: The software's architecture contains too many - or too few - horizontal layers.

title: Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor
comment: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.

title: Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
comment: The software creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.

title: Modules with Circular Dependencies
comment: The software contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

title: Invokable Control Element with Large Number of Outward Calls
comment: The code contains callable control elements that contain an excessively large number of references to other application objects external to the context of the callable, i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large.

title: Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table
comment: The software performs a data query with a large number of joins and sub-queries on a large data table.

title: Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop
comment: The software has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources, e.g. messaging, sessions, locks, or file descriptors.

title: Initialization with Hard-Coded Network Resource Configuration Data
comment: The software initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.

title: Excessive Use of Hard-Coded Literals in Initialization
comment: The software initializes a data element using a hard-coded literal that is not a simple integer or static constant element.

title: Missing Documentation for Design
comment: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed.

title: Invocation of a Control Element at an Unnecessarily Deep Horizontal Layer
comment: The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides at a deeper layer than the adjacent layer, i.e., the invocation skips at least one layer, and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer.

title: Multiple Inheritance from Concrete Classes
comment: The software contains a class with inheritance from more than one concrete class.

title: Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters
comment: A named-callable or method control element has a signature that supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.

title: Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
comment: The software uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.

title: Invokable Control Element in Multi-Thread Context with non-Final Static Storable or Member Element
comment: The code contains a function or method that operates in a multi-threaded environment but owns an unsafe non-final static storable or member data element.

title: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses
comment: The software performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

title: Parent Class with References to Child Class
comment: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class, its methods, or its members.

title: Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
comment: A static code block creates an instance of a class.

title: Invokable Control Element with Signature Containing an Excessive Number of Parameters
comment: The software contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of parameters/arguments.

title: Runtime Resource Management Control Element in a Component Built to Run on Application Servers
comment: The application uses deployed components from application servers, but it also uses low-level functions/methods for management of resources, instead of the API provided by the application server.

title: Missing Serialization Control Element
comment: The software contains a serializable data element that does not have an associated serialization method.

title: Excessive Execution of Sequential Searches of Data Resource
comment: The software contains a data query against an SQL table or view that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause sequential searches to be performed.

title: Inconsistency Between Implementation and Documented Design
comment: The implementation of the product is not consistent with the design as described within the relevant documentation.

title: Empty Exception Block
comment: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.

title: Serializable Data Element Containing non-Serializable Item Elements
comment: The software contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member, but the data element contains member elements that are not serializable.

title: Empty Code Block
comment: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.

title: Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling
comment: The software accesses a data resource through a database without using a connection pooling capability.

title: Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses
comment: The software contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses/queries that are sent through a data manager, i.e., does not use efficient database capabilities.

title: Class with Excessively Deep Inheritance
comment: A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it has a large number of parent classes.

title: Unconditional Control Flow Transfer outside of Switch Block
comment: The software performs unconditional control transfer (such as a goto) in code outside of a branching structure such as a switch block.

title: Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
comment: The code performs a comparison such as an equality test between two float (floating point) values, but it uses comparison operators that do not account for the possibility of loss of precision.

title: Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method
comment: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.

title: Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
comment: A source code file has too many lines of code.

title: Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element
comment: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.

title: Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
comment: The software is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.

title: Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations
comment: A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource.

title: Invokable Control Element with Excessive Volume of Commented-out Code
comment: A function, method, procedure, etc. contains an excessive amount of code that has been commented out within its body.

title: Class with Excessive Number of Child Classes
comment: A class contains an unnecessarily large number of children.

title: Class with Virtual Method without a Virtual Destructor
comment: A class contains a virtual method, but the method does not have an associated virtual destructor.

title: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
comment: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource, but there is no timeout for the call, or the timeout is set to infinite.

title: Large Data Table with Excessive Number of Indices
comment: The software uses a large data table that contains an excessively large number of indices.

title: Method Containing Access of a Member Element from Another Class
comment: A method for a class performs an operation that directly accesses a member element from another class.

title: Use of Object without Invoking Destructor Method
comment: The software contains a method that accesses an object but does not later invoke the element's associated finalize/destructor method.

title: Use of Same Invokable Control Element in Multiple Architectural Layers
comment: The software uses the same control element across multiple architectural layers.

title: Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource
comment: The software contains an index range scan for a large data table, but the scan can cover a large number of rows.

title: Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop
comment: The software uses a loop with a control flow condition based on a value that is updated within the body of the loop.

title: Persistent Storable Data Element without Associated Comparison Control Element
comment: The software uses a storable data element that does not have all of the associated functions or methods that are necessary to support comparison.

title: Data Element containing Pointer Item without Proper Copy Control Element
comment: The code contains a data element with a pointer that does not have an associated copy or constructor method.

title: Inconsistent Naming Conventions for Identifiers
comment: The product's code, documentation, or other artifacts do not consistently use the same naming conventions for variables, callables, groups of related callables, I/O capabilities, data types, file names, or similar types of elements.

title: Insufficient Isolation of System-Dependent Functions
comment: The product or code does not isolate system-dependent functionality into separate standalone modules.

title: Reliance on Runtime Component in Generated Code
comment: The product uses automatically-generated code that cannot be executed without a specific runtime support component.

title: Reliance on Machine-Dependent Data Representation
comment: The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors, physical machines, OSes, or other physical components.

title: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components
comment: The product relies on third-party software components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms.

title: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
comment: The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

title: Insufficient Encapsulation of Machine-Dependent Functionality
comment: The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality, but it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from the rest of the code.

title: Insufficient Use of Symbolic Constants
comment: The source code uses literal constants that may need to change or evolve over time, instead of using symbolic constants.

title: Insufficient Isolation of Symbolic Constant Definitions
comment: The source code uses symbolic constants, but it does not sufficiently place the definitions of these constants into a more centralized or isolated location.

title: Excessive Reliance on Global Variables
comment: The code is structured in a way that relies too much on using or setting global variables throughout various points in the code, instead of preserving the associated information in a narrower, more local context.

title: Use of Same Variable for Multiple Purposes
comment: The code contains a callable, block, or other code element in which the same variable is used to control more than one unique task or store more than one instance of data.

title: Incomplete Design Documentation
comment: The product's design documentation does not adequately describe control flow, data flow, system initialization, relationships between tasks, components, rationales, or other important aspects of the design.

title: Incomplete I/O Documentation
comment: The product's documentation does not adequately define inputs, outputs, or system/software interfaces.

title: Incomplete Documentation of Program Execution
comment: The document does not fully define all mechanisms that are used to control or influence how product-specific programs are executed.

title: Inappropriate Comment Style
comment: The source code uses comment styles or formats that are inconsistent or do not follow expected standards for the product.

title: Inappropriate Whitespace Style
comment: The source code contains whitespace that is inconsistent across the code or does not follow expected standards for the product.

title: Source Code Element without Standard Prologue
comment: The source code contains elements such as source files that do not consistently provide a prologue or header that has been standardized for the project.

title: Inaccurate Comments
comment: The source code contains comments that do not accurately describe or explain aspects of the portion of the code with which the comment is associated.

title: Callable with Insufficient Behavioral Summary
comment: The code contains a function or method whose signature and/or associated inline documentation does not sufficiently describe the callable's inputs, outputs, side effects, assumptions, or return codes.

title: Insufficient Documentation of Error Handling Techniques
comment: The documentation does not sufficiently describe the techniques that are used for error handling, exception processing, or similar mechanisms.

title: Excessive Use of Unconditional Branching
comment: The code uses too many unconditional branches (such as goto).

title: Excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
comment: The code contains McCabe cyclomatic complexity that exceeds a desirable maximum.

title: Excessive Halstead Complexity
comment: The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

title: Excessive Use of Self-Modifying Code
comment: The product uses too much self-modifying code.

title: Excessively Deep Nesting
comment: The code contains a callable or other code grouping in which the nesting / branching is too deep.

title: Excessive Attack Surface
comment: The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

title: Declaration of Variable with Unnecessarily Wide Scope
comment: The source code declares a variable in one scope, but the variable is only used within a narrower scope.

title: Compilation with Insufficient Warnings or Errors
comment: The code is compiled without sufficient warnings enabled, which may prevent the detection of subtle bugs or quality issues.

title: Improper Use of Validation Framework
comment: The application does not use, or incorrectly uses, an input validation framework that is provided by the source language or an independent library.

title: Insecure Default Initialization of Resource
comment: The software initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

title: Insufficient Granularity of Access Control
comment: The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However, implemented access controls lack required granularity, which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata
comment: The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information, but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original, sensitive information.

title: Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations
comment: The code uses boxed primitives, which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations.

title: Improper Neutralization of Formula Elements in a CSV File
comment: The software saves user-provided information into a Comma-Separated Value (CSV) file, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as a command when the file is opened by spreadsheet software.

title: Use of a Risky Cryptographic Primitive
comment: The product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard or unproven cryptographic primitive.

title: Use of Predictable Algorithm in Random Number Generator
comment: The product requires a true random number but uses an algorithm that is predictable and generates a pseudo-random number.

title: Observable Discrepancy
comment: The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor, which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

title: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-Chip (SoC)
comment: The product does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents.

title: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase
comment: The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

title: Exposed Chip Debug Interface With Insufficient Access Control
comment: The chip does not implement or does not correctly enforce access control on the debug interface, thus allowing an attacker to exercise the debug interface to access a portion of the chip internal registers that typically would not be exposed.

title: System-on-Chip (SoC) Using Components without Unique, Immutable Identifiers
comment: The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique, immutable identifiers for each of its components.

title: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control
comment: The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

title: Failure to Disable Reserved Bits
comment: The reserved bits in a hardware design are not disabled prior to production. Typically, reserved bits are used for future capabilities and should not support any functional logic in the design. However, designers might covertly use these bits to debug or further develop new capabilities in production hardware. Adversaries with access to these bits will write to them in hopes of compromising hardware state.

title: Incorrect Register Defaults or Module Parameters
comment: Hardware description language code incorrectly defines register defaults or hardware IP parameters to insecure values.

title: Race Condition for Write-Once Attributes
comment: A write-once register in hardware design is programmable by an untrusted software component earlier than the trusted software component, resulting in a race condition issue.

title: Improper Restriction of Write-Once Bit Fields
comment: The hardware design control register sticky bits or write-once bit fields are improperly implemented, such that they can be reprogrammed by software.

title: Improper Implementation of Lock Protection Registers
comment: The product incorrectly implements register lock bit protection features such that protected controls can be programmed even after the lock has been set.

title: Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition
comment: The product implements register lock bit protection features with the intent to disable changes to system configuration after the lock is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g., Entry and wake from low power sleep modes).

title: Improper Hardware Lock Protection for Security Sensitive Controls
comment: The product implements a register lock bit protection feature that permits security sensitive controls to modify the protected configuration.

title: Hardware Internal or Debug Modes Allow Override of Locks
comment: The product implements register lock bit protection features that may permit security sensitive controls to modify system configuration after the lock is set through internal modes or debug features.

title: Inclusion of Undocumented Features or Chicken Bits
comment: The chip includes chicken bits or undocumented features that can create entry points for unauthorized actors.

title: Exposure of Security-Sensitive Fuse Values During Debug
comment: The product exposes security-sensitive values stored in fuses during debug.

title: Improper Authorization on Physical Debug and Test Interfaces
comment: The product's physical debug and test interface protection does not block untrusted agents, resulting in unauthorized access to and potentially control of sensitive assets.

title: Improper Finite State Machines (FSMs) in Hardware Logic
comment: Faulty finite state machines (FSMs) in the hardware logic allow an attacker to put the system in an undefined state, to cause a denial of service (DoS) or gain privileges on the victim's system.

title: Improper Write Handling in Limited-write Non-Volatile Memories
comment: The product does not implement or incorrectly handles the implementation of write operations in limited-write non-volatile memories.

title: Missing Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches
comment: The product does not contain the necessary additional circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches.

title: Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications
comment: The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects.

title: Mirrored Regions with Different Values
comment: The product's architecture mirrors regions without ensuring that their contents always stay in sync.

title: CPU Hardware Not Configured to Support Exclusivity of Write and Execute Operations
comment: The CPU is not configured to provide hardware support for exclusivity of write and execute operations on memory. This allows an attacker to execute data from all of memory.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
comment: Information sent over a network can be compromised while in transit. An attacker may be able to read or modify the contents if the data are sent in plaintext or are weakly encrypted.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Insufficient Session-ID Length
comment: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
comment: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the software system.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Entity Bean Declared Remote
comment: When an application exposes a remote interface for an entity bean, it might also expose methods that get or set the bean's data. These methods could be leveraged to read sensitive information, or to change data in ways that violate the application's expectations, potentially leading to other vulnerabilities.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Weak Access Permissions for EJB Methods
comment: If elevated access rights are assigned to EJB methods, then an attacker can take advantage of the permissions to exploit the software system.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
comment: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
comment: An ASP .NET application must enable custom error pages in order to prevent attackers from mining information from the framework's built-in responses.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Password in Configuration File
comment: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource making them an easy target for attackers.

title: Compiler Removal of Code to Clear Buffers
comment: Sensitive memory is cleared according to the source code, but compiler optimizations leave the memory untouched when it is not read from again, aka dead store removal.

title: Improper Input Validation
comment: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates input that can affect the control flow or data flow of a program.

title: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the software does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.

title: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize ../ sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize /../ sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize /dir/../filename sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal ../ sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '..filedir'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize .. sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '..filename'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '..filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: 'dir..filename'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize 'dir..filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: 'dir....filename'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize 'dir....filename' (multiple internal backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '...' (Triple Dot)
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '...' (triple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '....' (Multiple Dot)
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....' (multiple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '....//'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....//' (doubled dot dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '.../...//'
comment: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '.../...//' (doubled triple dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

title: Path Traversal: '/absolute/pathname/here'
comment: A software system that accepts input in the form of a slash absolute path ('/absolute/pathname/here') without appropriate validation can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Traversal: 'absolutepathnamehere'
comment: A software system that accepts input in the form of a backslash absolute path ('absolutepathnamehere') without appropriate validation can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Traversal: 'C:dirname'
comment: An attacker can inject a drive letter or Windows volume letter ('C:dirname') into a software system to potentially redirect access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

title: Path Traversal: 'UNCsharename' (Windows UNC Share)
comment: An attacker can inject a Windows UNC share ('UNCsharename') into a software system to potentially redirect access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filename.' (Trailing Dot)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of trailing dot ('filedir.') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filename....' (Multiple Trailing Dot)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing dot ('filedir....') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'file.name' (Internal Dot)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of internal dot ('file.ordir') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'file...name' (Multiple Internal Dot)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple internal dot ('file...dir') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filename ' (Trailing Space)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of trailing space ('filedir ') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: ' filename' (Leading Space)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of leading space (' filedir') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'file name' (Internal Whitespace)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of internal space ('file(SPACE)name') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filename/' (Trailing Slash)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of trailing slash ('filedir/') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: '//multiple/leading/slash'
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple leading slash ('//multiple/leading/slash') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: '/multiple//internal/slash'
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple internal slash ('/multiple//internal/slash/') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: '/multiple/trailing/slash//'
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing slash ('/multiple/trailing/slash//') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'multipleinternalbackslash'
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of multiple internal backslash ('multipletrailingslash') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filedir' (Trailing Backslash)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of trailing backslash ('filedir') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: '/./' (Single Dot Directory)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of single dot directory exploit ('/./') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'filedir*' (Wildcard)
comment: A software system that accepts path input in the form of asterisk wildcard ('filedir*') without appropriate validation can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

title: Path Equivalence: 'fakedir/../realdir/filename'
comment: The software contains protection mechanisms to restrict access to 'realdir/filename', but it constructs pathnames using external input in the form of 'fakedir/../realdir/filename' that are not handled by those mechanisms. This allows attackers to perform unauthorized actions against the targeted file.

title: Path Equivalence: Windows 8.3 Filename
comment: The software contains a protection mechanism that restricts access to a long filename on a Windows operating system, but the software does not properly restrict access to the equivalent short 8.3 filename.

title: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following
comment: The software, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the software to operate on unauthorized files.

title: UNIX Hard Link
comment: The software, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the software to operate on unauthorized files.

title: Windows Shortcut Following (.LNK)
comment: The software, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the file is a Windows shortcut (.LNK) whose target is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the software to operate on unauthorized files.

title: Windows Hard Link
comment: The software, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the software to operate on unauthorized files.

title: Improper Handling of Windows Device Names
comment: The software constructs pathnames from user input, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a pathname containing a Windows device name such as AUX or CON. This typically leads to denial of service or an information exposure when the application attempts to process the pathname as a regular file.

title: Improper Handling of Windows ::DATA Alternate Data Stream
comment: The software does not properly prevent access to, or detect usage of, alternate data streams (ADS).

title: Improper Handling of Apple HFS+ Alternate Data Stream Path
comment: The software does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of a command, data structure, or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component.

title: Failure to Sanitize Special Elements into a Different Plane (Special Element Injection)
comment: The software does not adequately filter user-controlled input for special elements with control implications.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')
comment: The software constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Script-Related HTML Tags in a Web Page (Basic XSS)
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special characters such as <, >, and & that could be interpreted as web-scripting elements when they are sent to a downstream component that processes web pages.

title: Improper Neutralization of Script in an Error Message Web Page
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special characters that could be interpreted as web-scripting elements when they are sent to an error page.

title: Improper Neutralization of Script in Attributes of IMG Tags in a Web Page
comment: The web application does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes scripting elements within attributes of HTML IMG tags, such as the src attribute.

title: Improper Neutralization of Script in Attributes in a Web Page
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes javascript: or other URIs from dangerous attributes within tags, such as onmouseover, onload, onerror, or style.

title: Improper Neutralization of Encoded URI Schemes in a Web Page
comment: The web application improperly neutralizes user-controlled input for executable script disguised with URI encodings.

title: Doubled Character XSS Manipulations
comment: The web application does not filter user-controlled input for executable script disguised using doubling of the involved characters.

title: Improper Neutralization of Invalid Characters in Identifiers in Web Pages
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes invalid characters or byte sequences in the middle of tag names, URI schemes, and other identifiers.

title: Improper Neutralization of Alternate XSS Syntax
comment: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controlled input for alternate script syntax.

title: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before using the input in a dynamic evaluation call (e.g. eval).

title: Improper Neutralization of Server-Side Includes (SSI) Within a Web Page
comment: The software generates a web page, but does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input that could be interpreted as a server-side include (SSI) directive.

title: Improper Control of Filename for Include/Require Statement in PHP Program ('PHP Remote File Inclusion')
comment: The PHP application receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before its usage in require, include, or similar functions.

title: Improper Control of Resource Identifiers ('Resource Injection')
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before it is used as an identifier for a resource that may be outside the intended sphere of control.

title: Struts: Duplicate Validation Forms
comment: The application uses multiple validation forms with the same name, which might cause the Struts Validator to validate a form that the programmer does not expect.

title: Struts: Incomplete validate() Method Definition
comment: The application has a validator form that either does not define a validate() method, or defines a validate() method but does not call super.validate().

title: Struts: Form Bean Does Not Extend Validation Class
comment: If a form bean does not extend an ActionForm subclass of the Validator framework, it can expose the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

title: Struts: Form Field Without Validator
comment: The application has a form field that is not validated by a corresponding validation form, which can introduce other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

title: Struts: Plug-in Framework not in Use
comment: When an application does not use an input validation framework such as the Struts Validator, there is a greater risk of introducing weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

title: Struts: Unused Validation Form
comment: An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.

title: Struts: Unvalidated Action Form
comment: Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.

title: Struts: Validator Turned Off
comment: Automatic filtering via a Struts bean has been turned off, which disables the Struts Validator and custom validation logic. This exposes the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

title: Struts: Validator Without Form Field
comment: Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.

title: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI
comment: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.

title: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Response Splitting')
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CR and LF characters before the data is included in outgoing HTTP headers.

title: Process Control
comment: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.

title: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output
comment: The software prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

title: Incorrect Access of Indexable Resource ('Range Error')
comment: The software does not restrict or incorrectly restricts operations within the boundaries of a resource that is accessed using an index or pointer, such as memory or files.

title: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer
comment: The software performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

title: Stack-based Buffer Overflow
comment: A stack-based buffer overflow condition is a condition where the buffer being overwritten is allocated on the stack (i.e., is a local variable or, rarely, a parameter to a function).

title: Heap-based Buffer Overflow
comment: A heap overflow condition is a buffer overflow, where the buffer that can be overwritten is allocated in the heap portion of memory, generally meaning that the buffer was allocated using a routine such as malloc().

title: Buffer Over-read
comment: The software reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations after the targeted buffer.

title: Buffer Under-read
comment: The software reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations prior to the targeted buffer.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as control elements or syntactic markers when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Parameter/Argument Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as parameter or argument delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Value Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as value delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Record Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as record delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Line Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as line delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Section Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as section delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Expression/Command Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as expression or command delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Input Terminators
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as input terminators when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Input Leaders
comment: The application does not properly handle when a leading character or sequence (leader) is missing or malformed, or if multiple leaders are used when only one should be allowed.

title: Improper Neutralization of Quoting Syntax
comment: Quotes injected into an application can be used to compromise a system. As data are parsed, an injected/absent/duplicate/malformed use of quotes may cause the process to take unexpected actions.

title: Improper Neutralization of Escape, Meta, or Control Sequences
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as escape, meta, or control character sequences when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Comment Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as comment delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Macro Symbols
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as macro symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Substitution Characters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as substitution characters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Variable Name Delimiters
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as variable name delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Wildcards or Matching Symbols
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as wildcards or matching symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Whitespace
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as whitespace when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Failure to Sanitize Paired Delimiters
comment: The software does not properly handle the characters that are used to mark the beginning and ending of a group of entities, such as parentheses, brackets, and braces.

title: Improper Neutralization of Null Byte or NUL Character
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes NUL characters or null bytes when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Handling of Invalid Use of Special Elements
comment: The product does not properly filter, remove, quote, or otherwise manage the invalid use of special elements in user-controlled input, which could cause adverse effect on its behavior and integrity.

title: Improper Neutralization of Leading Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Leading Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Trailing Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Trailing Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Internal Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Internal Special Elements
comment: The software receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

title: Encoding Error
comment: The software does not properly encode or decode the data, resulting in unexpected values.

title: Improper Handling of Alternate Encoding
comment: The software does not properly handle when an input uses an alternate encoding that is valid for the control sphere to which the input is being sent.

title: Double Decoding of the Same Data
comment: The software decodes the same input twice, which can limit the effectiveness of any protection mechanism that occurs in between the decoding operations.

title: Improper Handling of Mixed Encoding
comment: The software does not properly handle when the same input uses several different (mixed) encodings.

title: Improper Handling of Unicode Encoding
comment: The software does not properly handle when an input contains Unicode encoding.

title: Improper Handling of URL Encoding (Hex Encoding)
comment: The software does not properly handle when all or part of an input has been URL encoded.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Canonicalize
comment: The software validates input before it is canonicalized, which prevents the software from detecting data that becomes invalid after the canonicalization step.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Filter
comment: The software validates data before it has been filtered, which prevents the software from detecting data that becomes invalid after the filtering step.

title: Incorrect Regular Expression
comment: The software specifies a regular expression in a way that causes data to be improperly matched or compared.

title: Partial String Comparison
comment: The software performs a comparison that only examines a portion of a factor before determining whether there is a match, such as a substring, leading to resultant weaknesses.

title: Unexpected Sign Extension
comment: The software performs an operation on a number that causes it to be sign extended when it is transformed into a larger data type. When the original number is negative, this can produce unexpected values that lead to resultant weaknesses.

title: Signed to Unsigned Conversion Error
comment: The software uses a signed primitive and performs a cast to an unsigned primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the signed primitive can not be represented using an unsigned primitive.

title: Unsigned to Signed Conversion Error
comment: The software uses an unsigned primitive and performs a cast to a signed primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the unsigned primitive can not be represented using a signed primitive.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
comment: The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Data Queries
comment: When trying to keep information confidential, an attacker can often infer some of the information by using statistics.

title: Observable Internal Behavioral Discrepancy
comment: The product performs multiple behaviors that are combined to produce a single result, but the individual behaviors are observable separately in a way that allows attackers to reveal internal state or internal decision points.

title: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy With Equivalent Products
comment: The product operates in an environment in which its existence or specific identity should not be known, but it behaves differently than other products with equivalent functionality, in a way that is observable to an attacker.

title: Self-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The software identifies an error condition and creates its own diagnostic or error messages that contain sensitive information.

title: Externally-Generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The application performs an operation that triggers an external diagnostic or error message that is not directly generated or controlled by the application, such as an error generated by the programming language interpreter that the software uses. The error can contain sensitive system information.

title: Storage of File with Sensitive Data Under Web Root
comment: The application stores sensitive data under the web document root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

title: Storage of File With Sensitive Data Under FTP Root
comment: The application stores sensitive data under the FTP server root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

title: Information Loss or Omission
comment: The software does not record, or improperly records, security-relevant information that leads to an incorrect decision or hampers later analysis.

title: Improper Handling of Syntactically Invalid Structure
comment: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles input that is not syntactically well-formed with respect to the associated specification.

title: Improper Handling of Missing Values
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when a parameter, field, or argument name is specified, but the associated value is missing, i.e. it is empty, blank, or null.

title: Improper Handling of Extra Values
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when more values are provided than expected.

title: Improper Handling of Undefined Values
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when a value is not defined or supported for the associated parameter, field, or argument name.

title: Failure to Handle Missing Parameter
comment: If too few arguments are sent to a function, the function will still pop the expected number of arguments from the stack. Potentially, a variable number of arguments could be exhausted in a function as well.

title: Improper Handling of Extra Parameters
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when the number of parameters, fields, or arguments with the same name exceeds the expected amount.

title: Improper Handling of Undefined Parameters
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular parameter, field, or argument name is not defined or supported by the product.

title: Improper Handling of Incomplete Structural Elements
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular structural element is not completely specified.

title: Failure to Handle Incomplete Element
comment: The software does not properly handle when a particular element is not completely specified.

title: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Structural Elements
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles when two or more structural elements should be consistent, but are not.

title: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
comment: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.

title: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
comment: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.

title: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
comment: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.

title: Empty Password in Configuration File
comment: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.

title: Use of Hard-coded Password
comment: The software contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

title: Improper Privilege Management
comment: The software does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

title: Privilege Dropping / Lowering Errors
comment: The software does not drop privileges before passing control of a resource to an actor that does not have those privileges.

title: Improper Ownership Management
comment: The software assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.

title: Improper Access Control
comment: The software does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

title: Improper Authorization
comment: The software does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

title: Incorrect User Management
comment: The software does not properly manage a user within its environment.

title: Improper Authentication
comment: When an actor claims to have a given identity, the software does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

title: Authentication Bypass by Alternate Name
comment: The software performs authentication based on the name of a resource being accessed, or the name of the actor performing the access, but it does not properly check all possible names for that resource or actor.

title: Reliance on IP Address for Authentication
comment: The software uses an IP address for authentication.

title: Using Referer Field for Authentication
comment: The referer field in HTTP requests can be easily modified and, as such, is not a valid means of message integrity checking.

title: Improper Validation of Certificate with Host Mismatch
comment: The software communicates with a host that provides a certificate, but the software does not properly ensure that the certificate is actually associated with that host.

title: Improper Validation of Certificate Expiration
comment: A certificate expiration is not validated or is incorrectly validated, so trust may be assigned to certificates that have been abandoned due to age.

title: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint
comment: The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint.

title: Reflection Attack in an Authentication Protocol
comment: Simple authentication protocols are subject to reflection attacks if a malicious user can use the target machine to impersonate a trusted user.

title: Authentication Bypass by Assumed-Immutable Data
comment: The authentication scheme or implementation uses key data elements that are assumed to be immutable, but can be controlled or modified by the attacker.

title: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
comment: The software does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission.

title: Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext in a file, or on disk.

title: Cleartext Storage in the Registry
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext in the registry.

title: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie.

title: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Memory
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext in memory.

title: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Executable
comment: The application stores sensitive information in cleartext in an executable.

title: Inadequate Encryption Strength
comment: The software stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required.

title: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
comment: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

title: Not Using a Random IV with CBC Mode
comment: Not using a random initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks.

title: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
comment: The software uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

title: Insufficient Entropy in PRNG
comment: The lack of entropy available for, or used by, a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) can be a stability and security threat.

title: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
comment: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block.

title: Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
comment: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses the same seed each time the product is initialized.

title: Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
comment: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) is initialized from a predictable seed, such as the process ID or system time.

title: Small Seed Space in PRNG
comment: A PRNG uses a relatively small space of seeds.

title: Generation of Predictable Numbers or Identifiers
comment: The product uses a scheme that generates numbers or identifiers that are more predictable than required.

title: Use of Invariant Value in Dynamically Changing Context
comment: The product uses a constant value, name, or reference, but this value can (or should) vary across different environments.

title: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity
comment: The software does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

title: Reliance on Reverse DNS Resolution for a Security-Critical Action
comment: The software performs reverse DNS resolution on an IP address to obtain the hostname and make a security decision, but it does not properly ensure that the IP address is truly associated with the hostname.

title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
comment: The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request.

title: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard
comment: The software does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm, protocol, or technique.

title: Trust of System Event Data
comment: Security based on event locations are insecure and can be spoofed.

title: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
comment: The program contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code, and the code sequence requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently.

title: Missing Check for Certificate Revocation after Initial Check
comment: The software does not check the revocation status of a certificate after its initial revocation check, which can cause the software to perform privileged actions even after the certificate is revoked at a later time.

title: Insecure Temporary File
comment: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

title: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
comment: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

title: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
comment: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

title: Session Fixation
comment: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
comment: The software does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

title: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
comment: The software does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, which slowly consumes remaining memory.

title: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')
comment: The software makes resources available to untrusted parties when those resources are only intended to be accessed by the software.

title: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
comment: The program does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

title: Asymmetric Resource Consumption (Amplification)
comment: Software that does not appropriately monitor or control resource consumption can lead to adverse system performance.

title: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)
comment: The software does not sufficiently monitor or control transmitted network traffic volume, so that an actor can cause the software to transmit more traffic than should be allowed for that actor.

title: Inefficient Algorithmic Complexity
comment: An algorithm in a product has an inefficient worst-case computational complexity that may be detrimental to system performance and can be triggered by an attacker, typically using crafted manipulations that ensure that the worst case is being reached.

title: Double Free
comment: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address, potentially leading to modification of unexpected memory locations.

title: Use After Free
comment: Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

title: Unprotected Windows Messaging Channel ('Shatter')
comment: The software does not properly verify the source of a message in the Windows Messaging System while running at elevated privileges, creating an alternate channel through which an attacker can directly send a message to the product.

title: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
comment: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

title: Improper Interaction Between Multiple Correctly-Behaving Entities
comment: An interaction error occurs when two entities have correct behavior when running independently of each other, but when they are integrated as components in a larger system or process, they introduce incorrect behaviors that may cause resultant weaknesses.

title: Interpretation Conflict
comment: Product A handles inputs or steps differently than Product B, which causes A to perform incorrect actions based on its perception of B's state.

title: Unintended Proxy or Intermediary ('Confused Deputy')
comment: The software receives a request, message, or directive from an upstream component, but the software does not sufficiently preserve the original source of the request before forwarding the request to an external actor that is outside of the software's control sphere. This causes the software to appear to be the source of the request, leading it to act as a proxy or other intermediary between the upstream component and the external actor.

title: UI Discrepancy for Security Feature
comment: The user interface does not correctly enable or configure a security feature, but the interface provides feedback that causes the user to believe that the feature is in a secure state.

title: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information
comment: The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user, allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks.

title: Insecure Default Variable Initialization
comment: The software, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

title: Missing Initialization of a Variable
comment: The software does not initialize critical variables, which causes the execution environment to use unexpected values.

title: Use of Uninitialized Variable
comment: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

title: PHP External Variable Modification
comment: A PHP application does not properly protect against the modification of variables from external sources, such as query parameters or cookies. This can expose the application to numerous weaknesses that would not exist otherwise.

title: Assigning instead of Comparing
comment: The code uses an operator for assignment when the intention was to perform a comparison.

title: Comparing instead of Assigning
comment: The code uses an operator for comparison when the intention was to perform an assignment.

title: Comparison of Classes by Name
comment: The program compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

title: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
comment: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

title: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
comment: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

title: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
comment: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

title: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
comment: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

title: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
comment: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

title: Cloneable Class Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class is cloneable. The data can then be accessed by cloning the class.

title: Serializable Class Containing Sensitive Data
comment: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class does not explicitly deny serialization. The data can be accessed by serializing the class through another class.

title: Public Static Field Not Marked Final
comment: An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways.

title: Embedded Malicious Code
comment: The application contains code that appears to be malicious in nature.

title: Trojan Horse
comment: The software appears to contain benign or useful functionality, but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator.

title: Non-Replicating Malicious Code
comment: Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or software that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems.

title: Replicating Malicious Code (Virus or Worm)
comment: Replicating malicious code, including viruses and worms, will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or software.

title: Trapdoor
comment: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input, allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

title: Logic/Time Bomb
comment: The software contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the software (or its environment) when a certain time passes, or when a certain logical condition is met.

title: Spyware
comment: The software collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities, but the software accesses this information using other resources besides itself, and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the software.

title: Covert Channel
comment: A covert channel is a path that can be used to transfer information in a way not intended by the system's designers.

title: .NET Misconfiguration: Use of Impersonation
comment: Allowing a .NET application to run at potentially escalated levels of access to the underlying operating and file systems can be dangerous and result in various forms of attacks.

title: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
comment: The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

title: Use of Web Browser Cache Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The web application does not use an appropriate caching policy that specifies the extent to which each web page and associated form fields should be cached.

title: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Environmental Variables
comment: Environmental variables may contain sensitive information about a remote server.

title: Exposure of Version-Control Repository to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
