comment: The product stores a CVS, git, or other repository in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

title: Exposure of Core Dump File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
comment: The product generates a core dump file in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

title: Exposure of Access Control List Files to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
comment: The product stores access control list files in a directory or other container that is accessible to actors outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Exposure of Backup File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
comment: A backup file is stored in a directory or archive that is made accessible to unauthorized actors.

title: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code
comment: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications, it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.

title: Exposure of Information Through Shell Error Message
comment: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

title: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in your web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

title: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

title: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory
comment: The product places sensitive information into files or directories that are accessible to actors who are allowed to have access to the files, but not to the sensitive information.

title: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.

title: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File
comment: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

title: Use of Singleton Pattern Without Synchronization in a Multithreaded Context
comment: The software uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.

title: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
comment: A directory listing is inappropriately exposed, yielding potentially sensitive information to attackers.

title: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
comment: Certain conditions, such as network failure, will cause a server error message to be displayed.

title: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties
comment: The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.

title: Command Shell in Externally Accessible Directory
comment: A possible shell file exists in /cgi-bin/ or other accessible directories. This is extremely dangerous and can be used by an attacker to execute commands on the web server.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Not Using Input Validation Framework
comment: The ASP.NET application does not use an input validation framework.

title: J2EE Misconfiguration: Plaintext Password in Configuration File
comment: The J2EE application stores a plaintext password in a configuration file.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Use of Identity Impersonation
comment: Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges.

title: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
comment: The application uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.

title: Use of umask() with chmod-style Argument
comment: The product calls umask() with an incorrect argument that is specified as if it is an argument to chmod().

title: SQL Injection: Hibernate
comment: Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with user-controlled input can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.

title: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key
comment: The software uses a database table that includes records that should not be accessible to an actor, but it executes a SQL statement with a primary key that can be controlled by that actor.

title: finalize() Method Without super.finalize()
comment: The software contains a finalize() method that does not call super.finalize().

title: Call to Thread run() instead of start()
comment: The program calls a thread's run() method instead of calling start(), which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee.

title: Improper Following of Specification by Caller
comment: The software does not follow or incorrectly follows the specifications as required by the implementation language, environment, framework, protocol, or platform.

title: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
comment: The program violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives.

title: EJB Bad Practices: Use of AWT Swing
comment: The program violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing.

title: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Java I/O
comment: The program violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package.

title: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets
comment: The program violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets.

title: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Class Loader
comment: The program violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader.

title: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session
comment: The application stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute, which can hurt reliability.

title: Array Declared Public, Final, and Static
comment: The program declares an array public, final, and static, which is not sufficient to prevent the array's contents from being modified.

title: finalize() Method Declared Public
comment: The program violates secure coding principles for mobile code by declaring a finalize() method public.

title: Call to Non-ubiquitous API
comment: The software uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences.

title: Free of Memory not on the Heap
comment: The application calls free() on a pointer to memory that was not allocated using associated heap allocation functions such as malloc(), calloc(), or realloc().

title: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory
comment: The application stores sensitive data in memory that is not locked, or that has been incorrectly locked, which might cause the memory to be written to swap files on disk by the virtual memory manager. This can make the data more accessible to external actors.

title: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created
comment: The software modifies the SSL context after connection creation has begun.

title: J2EE Framework: Saving Unserializable Objects to Disk
comment: When the J2EE container attempts to write unserializable objects to disk there is no guarantee that the process will complete successfully.

title: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings
comment: The web application uses the HTTP GET method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that requests.

title: Missing Validation of OpenSSL Certificate
comment: The software uses OpenSSL and trusts or uses a certificate without using the SSL_get_verify_result() function to ensure that the certificate satisfies all necessary security requirements.

title: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security
comment: The software is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server.

title: Public Static Final Field References Mutable Object
comment: A public or protected static final field references a mutable object, which allows the object to be changed by malicious code, or accidentally from another package.

title: Struts: Non-private Field in ActionForm Class
comment: An ActionForm class contains a field that has not been declared private, which can be accessed without using a setter or getter.

title: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere
comment: The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute
comment: The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.

title: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments
comment: While adding general comments is very useful, some programmers tend to leave important data, such as: filenames related to the web application, old links or links which were not meant to be browsed by users, old code fragments, etc.

title: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)
comment: The PHP application uses an old method for processing uploaded files by referencing the four global variables that are set for each file (e.g. $varname, $varname_size, $varname_name, $varname_type). These variables could be overwritten by attackers, causing the application to process unauthorized files.

title: Improper Validation of Function Hook Arguments
comment: A product adds hooks to user-accessible API functions, but does not properly validate the arguments. This could lead to resultant vulnerabilities.

title: Unsafe ActiveX Control Marked Safe For Scripting
comment: An ActiveX control is intended for restricted use, but it has been marked as safe-for-scripting.

title: Null Byte Interaction Error (Poison Null Byte)
comment: The product does not properly handle null bytes or NUL characters when passing data between different representations or components.

title: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
comment: When the product encounters an error condition or failure, its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available, such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions.

title: Unnecessary Complexity in Protection Mechanism (Not Using 'Economy of Mechanism')
comment: The software uses a more complex mechanism than necessary, which could lead to resultant weaknesses when the mechanism is not correctly understood, modeled, configured, implemented, or used.

title: Not Using Complete Mediation
comment: The software does not perform access checks on a resource every time the resource is accessed by an entity, which can create resultant weaknesses if that entity's rights or privileges change over time.

title: External Control of Critical State Data
comment: The software stores security-critical state information about its users, or the software itself, in a location that is accessible to unauthorized actors.

title: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax
comment: The application does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes web scripting syntax in HTTP headers that can be used by web browser components that can process raw headers, such as Flash.

title: Reliance on File Name or Extension of Externally-Supplied File
comment: The software allows a file to be uploaded, but it relies on the file name or extension of the file to determine the appropriate behaviors. This could be used by attackers to cause the file to be misclassified and processed in a dangerous fashion.

title: Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions
comment: The software defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the assumption that a URL is canonical. This can allow a non-canonical URL to bypass the authorization.

title: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side
comment: The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks, since some applications allow GET to modify state.

title: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information
comment: The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return).

title: Insufficient Compartmentalization
comment: The product does not sufficiently compartmentalize functionality or processes that require different privilege levels, rights, or permissions.

title: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision
comment: A protection mechanism relies exclusively, or to a large extent, on the evaluation of a single condition or the integrity of a single object or entity in order to make a decision about granting access to restricted resources or functionality.

title: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability
comment: The software has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use, encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism, whether by accident or on purpose.

title: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity
comment: The software uses a protection mechanism whose strength depends heavily on its obscurity, such that knowledge of its algorithms or key data is sufficient to defeat the mechanism.

title: Violation of Secure Design Principles
comment: The product violates well-established principles for secure design.

title: Improper Synchronization
comment: The software utilizes multiple threads or processes to allow temporary access to a shared resource that can only be exclusive to one process at a time, but it does not properly synchronize these actions, which might cause simultaneous accesses of this resource by multiple threads or processes.

title: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime
comment: The software does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

title: Improper Initialization
comment: The software does not initialize or incorrectly initializes a resource, which might leave the resource in an unexpected state when it is accessed or used.

title: Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime
comment: The software performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle, which can lead to unexpected behaviors.

title: Improper Locking
comment: The software does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource, leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors.

title: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere
comment: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

title: Incorrect Resource Transfer Between Spheres
comment: The product does not properly transfer a resource/behavior to another sphere, or improperly imports a resource/behavior from another sphere, in a manner that provides unintended control over that resource.

title: Always-Incorrect Control Flow Implementation
comment: The code contains a control flow path that does not reflect the algorithm that the path is intended to implement, leading to incorrect behavior any time this path is navigated.

title: Lack of Administrator Control over Security
comment: The product uses security features in a way that prevents the product's administrator from tailoring security settings to reflect the environment in which the product is being used. This introduces resultant weaknesses or prevents it from operating at a level of security that is desired by the administrator.

title: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release
comment: The software uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

title: External Influence of Sphere Definition
comment: The product does not prevent the definition of control spheres from external actors.

title: Uncontrolled Recursion
comment: The product does not properly control the amount of recursion that takes place, which consumes excessive resources, such as allocated memory or the program stack.

title: Duplicate Operations on Resource
comment: The product performs the same operation on a resource two or more times, when the operation should only be applied once.

title: Integer Overflow to Buffer Overflow
comment: The product performs a calculation to determine how much memory to allocate, but an integer overflow can occur that causes less memory to be allocated than expected, leading to a buffer overflow.

title: Incorrect Calculation
comment: The software performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management.

title: Function Call With Incorrect Order of Arguments
comment: The software calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the arguments in an incorrect order, leading to resultant weaknesses.

title: Incorrect Provision of Specified Functionality
comment: The code does not function according to its published specifications, potentially leading to incorrect usage.

title: Function Call With Incorrect Number of Arguments
comment: The software calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies too many arguments, or too few arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

title: Function Call With Incorrect Argument Type
comment: The software calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that is the wrong data type, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

title: Function Call With Incorrectly Specified Argument Value
comment: The software calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that contains the wrong value, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

title: Function Call With Incorrect Variable or Reference as Argument
comment: The software calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the wrong variable or reference as one of the arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

title: Permission Race Condition During Resource Copy
comment: The product, while copying or cloning a resource, does not set the resource's permissions or access control until the copy is complete, leaving the resource exposed to other spheres while the copy is taking place.

title: Unchecked Return Value to NULL Pointer Dereference
comment: The product does not check for an error after calling a function that can return with a NULL pointer if the function fails, which leads to a resultant NULL pointer dereference.

title: Insufficient Control Flow Management
comment: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

title: Incomplete Blacklist to Cross-Site Scripting
comment: The product uses a blacklist-based protection mechanism to defend against XSS attacks, but the blacklist is incomplete, allowing XSS variants to succeed.

title: Protection Mechanism Failure
comment: The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.

title: Incorrect Behavior Order
comment: The software performs multiple related behaviors, but the behaviors are performed in the wrong order in ways which may produce resultant weaknesses.

title: Incorrect Comparison
comment: The software compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

title: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions
comment: The software does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the software.

title: Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast
comment: The software does not correctly convert an object, resource, or structure from one type to a different type.

title: Incorrect Control Flow Scoping
comment: The software does not properly return control flow to the proper location after it has completed a task or detected an unusual condition.

title: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference
comment: The software uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

title: Improper Neutralization
comment: The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties at met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

title: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards
comment: The software does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to resultant weaknesses or increase the severity of the associated vulnerabilities.

title: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource
comment: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.

title: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions
comment: The software does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the software.

title: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions
comment: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.

title: Selection of Less-Secure Algorithm During Negotiation ('Algorithm Downgrade')
comment: A protocol or its implementation supports interaction between multiple actors and allows those actors to negotiate which algorithm should be used as a protection mechanism such as encryption or authentication, but it does not select the strongest algorithm that is available to both parties.

title: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior
comment: The software uses an API function, data structure, or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity.

title: Use of a One-Way Hash without a Salt
comment: The software uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the software does not also use a salt as part of the input.

title: Use of a One-Way Hash with a Predictable Salt
comment: The software uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the software uses a predictable salt as part of the input.

title: Free of Pointer not at Start of Buffer
comment: The application calls free() on a pointer to a memory resource that was allocated on the heap, but the pointer is not at the start of the buffer.

title: Mismatched Memory Management Routines
comment: The application attempts to return a memory resource to the system, but it calls a release function that is not compatible with the function that was originally used to allocate that resource.

title: Incorrect Short Circuit Evaluation
comment: The software contains a conditional statement with multiple logical expressions in which one of the non-leading expressions may produce side effects. This may lead to an unexpected state in the program after the execution of the conditional, because short-circuiting logic may prevent the side effects from occurring.

title: Missing Reference to Active File Descriptor or Handle
comment: The software does not properly maintain references to a file descriptor or handle, which prevents that file descriptor/handle from being reclaimed.

title: Allocation of File Descriptors or Handles Without Limits or Throttling
comment: The software allocates file descriptors or handles on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on how many descriptors can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

title: Missing Release of File Descriptor or Handle after Effective Lifetime
comment: The software does not release a file descriptor or handle after its effective lifetime has ended, i.e., after the file descriptor/handle is no longer needed.

title: Regular Expression without Anchors
comment: The software uses a regular expression to perform neutralization, but the regular expression is not anchored and may allow malicious or malformed data to slip through.

title: Use of RSA Algorithm without OAEP
comment: The software uses the RSA algorithm but does not incorporate Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP), which might weaken the encryption.

title: Improper Address Validation in IOCTL with METHOD_NEITHER I/O Control Code
comment: The software defines an IOCTL that uses METHOD_NEITHER for I/O, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates the addresses that are provided.

title: Exposed IOCTL with Insufficient Access Control
comment: The software implements an IOCTL with functionality that should be restricted, but it does not properly enforce access control for the IOCTL.

title: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision
comment: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie, but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user.

title: Use of Path Manipulation Function without Maximum-sized Buffer
comment: The software invokes a function for normalizing paths or file names, but it provides an output buffer that is smaller than the maximum possible size, such as PATH_MAX.

title: Uncontrolled Memory Allocation
comment: The product allocates memory based on an untrusted size value, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates the size, allowing arbitrary amounts of memory to be allocated.

title: Improper Filtering of Special Elements
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but does not filter or incorrectly filters special elements before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Incomplete Filtering of One or More Instances of Special Elements
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but does not completely filter one or more instances of special elements before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Only Filtering One Instance of a Special Element
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but only filters a single instance of a special element before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Incomplete Filtering of Multiple Instances of Special Elements
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but does not filter all instances of a special element before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Only Filtering Special Elements Relative to a Marker
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements positioned relative to a marker (e.g. at the beginning/end of a string; the second argument), thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Only Filtering Special Elements at an Absolute Position
comment: The software receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements at an absolute position (e.g. byte number 10), thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

title: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency
comment: The software does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor, such as the number of incoming requests.

title: Buffer Access Using Size of Source Buffer
comment: The software uses the size of a source buffer when reading from or writing to a destination buffer, which may cause it to access memory that is outside of the bounds of the buffer.

title: Reliance on Untrusted Inputs in a Security Decision
comment: The application uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input, but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism.

title: Improper Control of Document Type Definition
comment: The software does not restrict a reference to a Document Type Definition (DTD) to the intended control sphere. This might allow attackers to reference arbitrary DTDs, possibly causing the software to expose files, consume excessive system resources, or execute arbitrary http requests on behalf of the attacker.

title: Inclusion of Web Functionality from an Untrusted Source
comment: The software includes web functionality (such as a web widget) from another domain, which causes it to operate within the domain of the software, potentially granting total access and control of the software to the untrusted source.

title: Excessive Iteration
comment: The software performs an iteration or loop without sufficiently limiting the number of times that the loop is executed.

title: Missing Authorization
comment: The software does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

title: Incorrect Authorization
comment: The software performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action, but it does not correctly perform the check. This allows attackers to bypass intended access restrictions.

title: Hidden Functionality
comment: The software contains functionality that is not documented, not part of the specification, and not accessible through an interface or command sequence that is obvious to the software's users or administrators.

title: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources
comment: The software does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements.

title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
comment: The web server receives a URL or similar request from an upstream component and retrieves the contents of this URL, but it does not sufficiently ensure that the request is being sent to the expected destination.

title: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information
comment: The software stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors.

title: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints
comment: The software establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

title: Improper Verification of Intent by Broadcast Receiver
comment: The Android application uses a Broadcast Receiver that receives an Intent but does not properly verify that the Intent came from an authorized source.

title: Improper Export of Android Application Components
comment: The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.

title: Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication
comment: The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications.

title: Overly Permissive Cross-domain Whitelist
comment: The software uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic
comment: The application generates a query intended to access or manipulate data in a data store such as a database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that can modify the intended logic of the query.

title: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
comment: The software uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag.

title: Use of Web Link to Untrusted Target with window.opener Access
comment: The web application produces links to untrusted external sites outside of its sphere of control, but it does not properly prevent the external site from modifying security-critical properties of the window.opener object, such as the location property.

title: Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
comment: The software performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity, but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors.

title: Insecure Automated Optimizations
comment: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.

title: Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations
comment: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.

title: Static Member Data Element outside of a Singleton Class Element
comment: The code contains a member element that is declared as static (but not final), in which its parent class element is not a singleton class - that is, a class element that can be used only once in the 'to' association of a Create action.

title: Incomplete Documentation
comment: The documentation, whether on paper or in electronic form, does not contain descriptions of all the relevant elements of the product, such as its usage, structure, interfaces, design, implementation, configuration, operation, etc.

title: Insufficient Encapsulation
comment: The software does not sufficiently hide the internal representation and implementation details of data or methods, which might allow external components or modules to modify data unexpectedly, invoke unexpected functionality, or introduce dependencies that the programmer did not intend.

title: Insufficient Adherence to Expected Conventions
comment: The product's architecture, source code, design, documentation, or other artifact does not follow required conventions.

title: Inappropriate Source Code Style or Formatting
comment: The source code does not follow desired style or formatting for indentation, white space, comments, etc.

title: Excessively Complex Data Representation
comment: The software uses an unnecessarily complex internal representation for its data structures or interrelationships between those structures.

title: Singleton Class Instance Creation without Proper Locking or Synchronization
comment: The software implements a Singleton design pattern but does not use appropriate locking or other synchronization mechanism to ensure that the singleton class is only instantiated once.

title: Excessive Code Complexity
comment: The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined, quantitative measure.

title: Irrelevant Code
comment: The program contains code that is not essential for execution, i.e. makes no state changes and has no side effects that alter data or control flow, such that removal of the code would have no impact to functionality or correctness.

title: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Improper Model Validation
comment: The ASP.NET application does not use, or incorrectly uses, the model validation framework.

title: Inefficient CPU Computation
comment: The program performs CPU computations using algorithms that are not as efficient as they could be for the needs of the developer, i.e., the computations can be optimized further.

title: Use of Prohibited Code
comment: The software uses a function, library, or third party component that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or the customer.

title: Insufficient Granularity of Address Regions Protected by Register Locks
comment: The product defines a large address region protected from modification by the same register lock control bit. This results in a conflict between the functional requirement that some addresses need to be writable by software during operation and the security requirement that the system configuration lock bit must be set during the boot process.

title: Creation of Emergent Resource
comment: The product manages resources or behaves in a way that indirectly creates a new, distinct resource that can be used by attackers in violation of the intended policy.

title: Improper Zeroization of Hardware Register
comment: The hardware product does not properly clear sensitive information from built-in registers when the user of the hardware block changes.

title: Application-Level Admin Tool with Inconsistent View of Underlying Operating System
comment: The product provides an application for administrators to manage parts of the underlying operating system, but the application does not accurately identify all of the relevant entities or resources that exist in the OS; that is, the application's model of the OS's state is inconsistent with the OS's actual state.

title: Improper Preservation of Consistency Between Independent Representations of Shared State
comment: The product has or supports multiple distributed components or sub-systems that are each required to keep their own local copy of shared data - such as state or cache - but the product does not ensure that all local copies remain consistent with each other.

title: Kat says Yay!
comment: Kat says Yay!
author: Kat

title: Types - Primitive
comment: When you access a primitive type you work directly on its value.

title: Types - Complex
comment: When you access a complex type you work on a reference to its value.

title: References - Const
comment: Use const for all of your references; avoid using var. eslint: prefer-const, no-const-assign

title: References - Reassign
comment: If you must reassign references, use let instead of var. eslint: no-var

title: References - Block vs. Function scoped
comment: Note that both let and const are block-scoped, whereas var is function-scoped.

title: Objects - literal syntax
comment: Use the literal syntax for object creation. eslint: no-new-object

title: Objects - dynamic property names
comment: Use computed property names when creating objects with dynamic property names.

title: Objects - object method shorthand
comment: Use object method shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand

title: Objects - property value shorthand
comment: Use property value shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand

title: Objects - group shorthand properties
comment: Group your shorthand properties at the beginning of your object declaration.

title: Objects - quote properties for invalid identifiers
comment: Only quote properties that are invalid identifiers. eslint: quote-props

title: Objects - do not call Object.prototype methods directly
comment: Do not call Object.prototype methods directly, such as hasOwnProperty, propertyIsEnumerable, and isPrototypeOf. eslint: no-prototype-builtins

title: Objects - object spread syntax for shallow-copy objects
comment: Prefer the object spread syntax over Object.assign to shallow-copy objects. Use the object rest operator to get a new object with certain properties omitted. eslint: prefer-object-spread

title: Arrays - creation
comment: Use the literal syntax for array creation. eslint: no-array-constructor

title: Arrays - use push to add
comment: Use Array#push instead of direct assignment to add items to an array.

title: Arrays - use spreads to copy
comment: Use array spreads ... to copy arrays.

title: Arrays - use spreads to convert
comment: To convert an iterable object to an array, use spreads ... instead of Array.from.

title: Arrays - use from to convert
comment: Use Array.from for converting an array-like object to an array.

title: Arrays - use from for mapping overable iterables
comment: Use Array.from instead of spread ... for mapping over iterables, because it avoids creating an intermediate array.

title: Arrays - use return states in array method call backs
comment: Use return statements in array method callbacks. It’s ok to omit the return if the function body consists of a single statement returning an expression without side effects, following 8.2. eslint: array-callback-return

title: Arrays - use line breaks
comment: Use line breaks after open and before close array brackets if an array has multiple lines

title: Object Destructuring
comment: Use object destructuring when accessing and using multiple properties of an object. eslint: prefer-destructuring

title: Array Destructuring
comment: Use array destructuring. eslint: prefer-destructuring

title: Multuple Return Value Destructuring
comment: Use object destructuring for multiple return values, not array destructuring.

title: Strings - use single quotes
comment: Use single quotes '' for strings. eslint: quotes

title: Strings - multuple lines
comment: Strings that cause the line to go over 100 characters should not be written across multiple lines using string concatenation.

title: Strings - templates
comment: When programmatically building up strings, use template strings instead of concatenation. eslint: prefer-template template-curly-spacing

title: Strings - do not use eval()
comment: Never use eval() on a string, it opens too many vulnerabilities. eslint: no-eval

title: Strings - use escape characters sparingly
comment: Do not unnecessarily escape characters in strings. eslint: no-useless-escape

title: Functions - use nameed function expressions
comment: Use named function expressions instead of function declarations. eslint: func-style

title: Functions - wrap in parantheses
comment: Wrap immediately invoked function expressions in parentheses. eslint: wrap-iife

title: Functions - never declare a function in a non-function block
comment: Never declare a function in a non-function block (if, while, etc). Assign the function to a variable instead. Browsers will allow you to do it, but they all interpret it differently, which is bad news bears. eslint: no-loop-func

title: Functions - ECMA-262 defines a block as a list of statements
comment: Note: ECMA-262 defines a block as a list of statements. A function declaration is not a statement.

title: Functions - Never name a parameter arguments
comment: Never name a parameter arguments. This will take precedence over the arguments object that is given to every function scope.

title: Functions - Never use arguments
comment: Never use arguments, opt to use rest syntax ... instead. eslint: prefer-rest-params

title: Functions - Use default parameter syntax rather than mutating function arguments
comment: Use default parameter syntax rather than mutating function arguments.

title: Functions - Avoid side effects with default parameters
comment: Avoid side effects with default parameters.

title: Functions - Always put default parameters last
comment: Always put default parameters last. eslint: default-param-last

title: Functions - Never use the Function constructor to create a new function
comment: Never use the Function constructor to create a new function. eslint: no-new-func

title: Functions - Spacing in a function signature
comment: Spacing in a function signature. eslint: space-before-function-paren space-before-blocks

title: Functions - Never mutate parameters
comment: Never mutate parameters. eslint: no-param-reassign

title: Functions - Never reassign parameters
comment: Never reassign parameters. eslint: no-param-reassign

title: Functions - Prefer the use of the spread syntax ... to call variadic functions
comment: Prefer the use of the spread syntax ... to call variadic functions. eslint: prefer-spread

title: Functions - Functions with multiline signatures, or invocations, should be indented
comment: Functions with multiline signatures, or invocations, should be indented just like every other multiline list in this guide: with each item on a line by itself, with a trailing comma on the last item. eslint: function-paren-newline

title: Arrow Functions - use arrow function notationfor anonymous function
comment: When you must use an anonymous function (as when passing an inline callback), use arrow function notation. eslint: prefer-arrow-callback, arrow-spacing

title: Arrow Functions - omit the braces
comment: If the function body consists of a single statement returning an expression without side effects, omit the braces and use the implicit return. Otherwise, keep the braces and use a return statement. eslint: arrow-parens, arrow-body-style

title: Arrow Functions - wrap multiple line expressions in parentheses
comment: In case the expression spans over multiple lines, wrap it in parentheses for better readability.

title: Arrow Functions - always include parentheses around arguments
comment: Always include parentheses around arguments for clarity and consistency. eslint: arrow-parens

title: Arrow Functions - avoid confusing arrow function syntax (=>) with comparison operators (<=, >=)
comment: Avoid confusing arrow function syntax (=>) with comparison operators (<=, >=). eslint: no-confusing-arrow

title: Arrow Functions - Enforce the location of arrow function bodies with implicit returns. eslint: implicit-arrow-linebreak
comment: Enforce the location of arrow function bodies with implicit returns. eslint: implicit-arrow-linebreak

title: Classes & Constructors - Always use class
comment: Always use class. Avoid manipulating prototype directly.

title: Classes & Constructors - Use extends for inheritance.
comment: Use extends for inheritance.

title: Classes & Constructors - Methods can return this to help with method chaining
comment: Methods can return this to help with method chaining.

title: Classes & Constructors -custom toString()
comment: It’s okay to write a custom toString() method, just make sure it works successfully and causes no side effects.

title: Classes & Constructors - default constructor
comment: Classes have a default constructor if one is not specified. An empty constructor function or one that just delegates to a parent class is unnecessary. eslint: no-useless-constructor

title: Classes & Constructors - Avoid duplicate class members
comment: Avoid duplicate class members. eslint: no-dupe-class-members

title: Classes & Constructors - Class methods
comment: Class methods should use this or be made into a static method unless an external library or framework requires using specific non-static methods. Being an instance method should indicate that it behaves differently based on properties of the receiver. eslint: class-methods-use-this

title: Awesome job meeting functional requirements
comment: Awesome job meeting functional requirements

title: Meets functional requirements
comment: Meets functional requirements

title: Functional requirements not met - Business Rules
comment: Functional requirements not met - Business Rules

title: Functional requirements not met - Transaction corrections, adjustments and cancellations
comment: Functional requirements not met - Transaction corrections, adjustments and cancellations

title: Functional requirements not met - Administrative functions
comment: Functional requirements not met - Administrative functions

title: Functional requirements not met - Authentication
comment: Functional requirements not met - Authentication

title: Functional requirements not met - Authorization levels
comment: Functional requirements not met - Authorization levels

comment: Functional requirements not met - Audit Tracking

comment: Functional requirements not met - External Interfaces

title: Functional requirements not met - Certification Requirements
comment: Functional requirements not met - Certification Requirements

title: Functional requirements not met - Reporting Requirements
comment: Functional requirements not met - Reporting Requirements

title: Functional requirements not met - Historical Data
comment: Functional requirements not met - Historical Data

title: Functional requirements not met - Legal / Regulatory Requirements
comment: Functional requirements not met - Legal / Regulatory Requirements

comment: Functional requirements not met - User Experience

title: Competence - met
comment: This code is in keeping with our value of competence: it was delivered on time, or you acknowledged it was not going to be delivered on time.
author: Sema Engineering

title: Competence - not met
comment: This code is not in keeping with our value of competence: it was not delivered on time, or you did not acknowledge it was going to be delivered behind schedule. Next time…
author: Sema Engineering

title: Scrappiness - met
comment: This code is in keeping with our value of scrappiness: it was a proper mix of quality and speed, allowing the team to give you feedback and not waste your time.
author: Sema Engineering

title: Scrappiness - not met
comment: This code is not in keeping with our value of scrappiness: it was not the right balance of quality and speed because …
author: Sema Engineering

title: Excellence - met
comment: This code is in keeping with our value of excellence: this was a situation that called for the highest level of quality, and this code delivered on that requirement.
author: Sema Engineering

title: Excellence - not met
comment: This code is not in keeping with our value of excellence: …
author: Sema Engineering

title: Growth - met
comment: This code is in keeping with our value of growth: you figured out something new, or you asked for help, or you raised a concern. Specifically ...
author: Sema Engineering

title: Growth - not met
comment: This code is not in keeping with our value of growth, because …
author: Sema Engineering

title: Ownership - met
comment: This code is in keeping with our value of ownership: you did what needed to be done to make sure it was a success.
author: Sema Engineering

title: Ownership - not met
comment: This code is not in keeping with our value of ownership because …
author: Sema Engineering

title: Modules - Always use modules over a non-standard module system
comment: Always use modules (import/export) over a non-standard module system. You can always transpile to your preferred module system.

title: Modules - Do not use wildcard imports
comment: Do not use wildcard imports.

title: Modules - Do not export directly from an import
comment: And do not export directly from an import.

title: Modules - Only import from a path in one place
comment: Only import from a path in one place. eslint: no-duplicate-imports

title: Modules - Do not export mutable bindings
comment: Do not export mutable bindings. eslint: import/no-mutable-exports

title: Modules - default export over named export
comment: In modules with a single export, prefer default export over named export. eslint: import/prefer-default-export

title: Modules - Put all imports above non-import statements
comment: Put all imports above non-import statements. eslint: import/first

title: Modules - Multiline imports intendenting
comment: Multiline imports should be indented just like multiline array and object literals. eslint: object-curly-newline

title: Modules - Disallow Webpack loader syntax in module import statements
comment: Disallow Webpack loader syntax in module import statements. eslint: import/no-webpack-loader-syntax

title: Modules - Do not include JavaScript filename extensions eslint: import/extensions
comment: Do not include JavaScript filename extensions eslint: import/extensions

title: Iterators and Generators - Don’t use iterators
comment: Don’t use iterators. Prefer JavaScript’s higher-order functions instead of loops like for-in or for-of. eslint: no-iterator no-restricted-syntax

title: Iterators and Generators- Don’t use generators
comment: Don’t use generators for now.

title: Generator function signature spacing
comment: If you must use generators, or if you disregard our advice, make sure their function signature is spaced properly. eslint: generator-star-spacing

title: Properties - Use dot notation when accessing properties
comment: Use dot notation when accessing properties. eslint: dot-notation

title: Properties - Use bracket notation [] when accessing properties with a variable
comment: Use bracket notation [] when accessing properties with a variable.

title: Properties - Use exponentiation operator ** when calculating exponentiations
comment: Use exponentiation operator ** when calculating exponentiations.

title: Variables -Always use const or let to declare variables.
comment: Variables -Always use const or let to declare variables. Not doing so will result in global variables. We want to avoid polluting the global namespace. Captain Planet warned us of that. eslint: no-undef prefer-const

title: Variables -Use one const or let declaration per variable or assignment
comment: Variables -Use one const or let declaration per variable or assignment. eslint: one-var

title: Variables -Group all your consts and then group all your lets
comment: Variables -Group all your consts and then group all your lets.

title: Variables -Assign variables where you need them
comment: Variables -Assign variables where you need them, but place them in a reasonable place.

title: Variables -Don’t chain variable assignments
comment: Variables -Don’t chain variable assignments. eslint: no-multi-assign

title: Variables -Avoid using unary increments and decrements (++, --)
comment: Variables -Avoid using unary increments and decrements (++, --). eslint no-plusplus

title: Variables -Avoid linebreaks before or after = in an assignment
comment: Variables -Avoid linebreaks before or after = in an assignment. If your assignment violates max-len, surround the value in parens. eslint operator-linebreak.

title: Variables -Disallow unused variables
comment: Variables -Disallow unused variables. eslint: no-unused-vars

title: Hoisting - var declarations get hoisted to the top of their closest enclosing function scope
comment: var declarations get hoisted to the top of their closest enclosing function scope, their assignment does not

title: Hoisting - Anonymous function expressions hoist their variable name, but not the function assignment
comment: Anonymous function expressions hoist their variable name, but not the function assignment.

title: Hoisting - Named function expressions hoist the variable name, not the function name or the function body
comment: Named function expressions hoist the variable name, not the function name or the function body.

title: Hoisting - Function declarations hoist their name and the function body
comment: Function declarations hoist their name and the function body.

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Use === and !== over == and !=. eslint: eqeqeq
comment: Use === and !== over == and !=. eslint: eqeqeq

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Conditional statements
comment:
Conditional statements such as the if statement evaluate their expression using coercion with the ToBoolean abstract method and always follow these simple rules:

Objects evaluate to true
Undefined evaluates to false
Null evaluates to false
Booleans evaluate to the value of the boolean
Numbers evaluate to false if +0, -0, or NaN, otherwise true
Strings evaluate to false if an empty string '', otherwise true

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Use shortcuts for booleans, but explicit comparisons for strings and numbers
comment: Use shortcuts for booleans, but explicit comparisons for strings and numbers.

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - For more information see Truth Equality and JavaScript by Angus Croll
comment: For more information see Truth Equality and JavaScript by Angus Croll.

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Use braces to create blocks in case and default clauses that contain lexical declarations (e.g. let, const, function, and class)
comment: Use braces to create blocks in case and default clauses that contain lexical declarations (e.g. let, const, function, and class). eslint: no-case-declarations

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Ternaries should not be nested
comment: Ternaries should not be nested and generally be single line expressions. eslint: no-nested-ternary

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - Avoid unneeded ternary statements
comment: Avoid unneeded ternary statements. eslint: no-unneeded-ternary

title: Comparison Operators & Equality - When mixing operators, enclose them in parentheses
comment: When mixing operators, enclose them in parentheses.

title: Blocks - Use braces with all multiline blocks
comment: Use braces with all multiline blocks. eslint: nonblock-statement-body-position

title: Blocks - multiline blocks with if and else
comment: If you’re using multiline blocks with if and else, put else on the same line as your if block’s closing brace. eslint: brace-style

title: Blocks - If an if block always executes a return statement, the subsequent else block is unnecessary
comment: If an if block always executes a return statement, the subsequent else block is unnecessary. A return in an else if block following an if block that contains a return can be separated into multiple if blocks. eslint: no-else-return

title: Control Statements - new lines for long control statements
comment: In case your control statement (if, while etc.) gets too long or exceeds the maximum line length, each (grouped) condition could be put into a new line. The logical operator should begin the line.

title: Control Statements - Don't use selection operators in place of control statements
comment: Don't use selection operators in place of control statements.

title: Comments - multiline
comment: Use /** ... */ for multiline comments.

title: Comments - single line
comment: Use // for single line comments. Place single line comments on a newline above the subject of the comment. Put an empty line before the comment unless it’s on the first line of a block.

title: Comments - Start all comments with a space
comment: Start all comments with a space to make it easier to read. eslint: spaced-comment

title: Comments - Prefixing your comments with FIXME or TODO
comment: Prefixing your comments with FIXME or TODO helps other developers quickly understand if you’re pointing out a problem that needs to be revisited, or if you’re suggesting a solution to the problem that needs to be implemented. These are different than regular comments because they are actionable. The actions are FIXME: -- need to figure this out or TODO: -- need to implement.

title: Comments - Use // FIXME: to annotate problems.
comment: Use // FIXME: to annotate problems.

title: Comments - Use // TODO: to annotate solutions to problems.
comment: Use // TODO: to annotate solutions to problems.

title: Whitespace - Use soft tabs (space character) set to 2 spaces
comment: Use soft tabs (space character) set to 2 spaces. eslint: indent

title: Whitespace - lace 1 space before the leading brace
comment: lace 1 space before the leading brace. eslint: space-before-blocks

title: Whitespace - keyword spacing
comment: Place 1 space before the opening parenthesis in control statements (if, while etc.). Place no space between the argument list and the function name in function calls and declarations. eslint: keyword-spacing

title: Whitespace - Set off operators with spaces
comment: Set off operators with spaces. eslint: space-infix-ops

title: Whitespace - End files with a single newline character
comment: End files with a single newline character. eslint: eol-last

title: Whitespace - Use indentation when making long method chains
comment: Use indentation when making long method chains (more than 2 method chains). Use a leading dot, which emphasizes that the line is a method call, not a new statement. eslint: newline-per-chained-call no-whitespace-before-property

title: Whitespace - Leave a blank line after blocks and before the next statement
comment: Leave a blank line after blocks and before the next statement.

title: Whitespace - Do not pad your blocks with blank lines
comment: Do not pad your blocks with blank lines. eslint: padded-blocks

title: Whitespace - Do not use multiple blank lines to pad your code
comment: Do not use multiple blank lines to pad your code. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines

title: Whitespace - Do not add spaces inside parentheses
comment: Do not add spaces inside parentheses. eslint: space-in-parens

title: Whitespace - Do not add spaces inside brackets
comment: Do not add spaces inside brackets. eslint: array-bracket-spacing

title: Whitespace - Add spaces inside curly braces
comment: Add spaces inside curly braces. eslint: object-curly-spacing

title: Whitespace - Avoid having lines of code that are longer than 100 characters
comment: Avoid having lines of code that are longer than 100 characters (including whitespace). Note: per above, long strings are exempt from this rule, and should not be broken up. eslint: max-len

title: Whitespace - Require consistent spacing inside an open block token and the next token on the same line
comment: Require consistent spacing inside an open block token and the next token on the same line. This rule also enforces consistent spacing inside a close block token and previous token on the same line. eslint: block-spacing

title: Whitespace - Avoid spaces before commas and require a space after commas
comment: Avoid spaces before commas and require a space after commas. eslint: comma-spacing

title: Whitespace - Enforce spacing inside of computed property brackets
comment: Enforce spacing inside of computed property brackets. eslint: computed-property-spacing

title: Whitespace - Avoid spaces between functions and their invocations
comment: Avoid spaces between functions and their invocations. eslint: func-call-spacing

title: Whitespace - Enforce spacing between keys and values in object literal properties
comment: Enforce spacing between keys and values in object literal properties. eslint: key-spacing

title: Whitespace - Avoid trailing spaces at the end of lines
comment: Avoid trailing spaces at the end of lines. eslint: no-trailing-spaces

title: Whitespace - Avoid multiple empty lines
comment: Avoid multiple empty lines, only allow one newline at the end of files, and avoid a newline at the beginning of files. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines
